SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

There is no need to remind honourable senators that since taking office the Hawke Government has embarked on an unprecedented program of reform and development in the aviation sector. Both the aviation industry and the community at large stand to benefit greatly from the changes involved.
The decisions taken to date have been substantial and have been an integral part of the Government's agenda of micro-economic reform both in the private and public sectors.

Faced with an industry hamstrung by 38 years of detailed economic regulation of interstate aviation, the Government's first reform priority was to put in place new arrangements designed to promote increased competition and pricing flexibility which would lead to greater economic efficiency in the industry and benefits to the consumer.
Consequently, the Government decided in October 1987 to give the required three years notice of termination of the two airlines agreement and move in 1990 to a deregulated domestic aviation system.
The Bill currently before the Senate gives effect to this decision.
The Bill brings to an end the two airlines policy, and opens Australia's inter-state air services to free competition.
On enactment of the Bill, the following legislation will be repealed:
Airlines Agreement Act 1981
Airlines Equipment Act 1958
Independent Air Fares Committee Act 1981
In addition, action has been taken to repeal Customs (prohibited imports) Regulation 4N, which currently controls the import of aircraft into Australia.
The net effect of these actions will be that the Commonwealth will withdraw from the detailed economic regulation of the domestic airline industry.

First, the current controls over the importation of aircraft will be removed. These controls have provided the threshold underpinning of the legislative and contractual arrangements which currently regulate the industry.
Secondly, the detailed determination of passenger capacity that may be provided by each trunk airline will cease.
Thirdly, the existing constraints on the entry of new domestic operators to trunk routes will be removed.
Finally, the Independent Air Fares Committee will be abolished and the Commonwealth will withdraw from the determination of air fares.

The Government is, however, determined to ensure that Australia's high safety record is maintained. It will also continue to maintain the highest level of aviation security and ensure that the aviation system is similarly geared to national environmental priorities.

What the Government expects is a general improvement, over time, in the competitive environment with the airlines free to develop their own commercial initiatives which should flow through to the advantage of consumers.
The benefits which can reasonably be expected to result from the increased opportunities for competition in a deregulated environment include:
greater incentives for existing and new participants to develop the industry in ways which are more efficient and responsive to consumer needs
a wider range of fares, in particular an increased availability of discount fares
growth, particularly in the price sensitive leisure market
a greater variety in the types, standards and frequency of services provided, and use of more appropriate aircraft on some routes
Following deregulation the domestic aviation market will be required to operate within the constraints of established competition policy controls applicable to industry generally.

Interstate air fares will be made subject to surveillance by the Prices Surveillance Authority. The discipline that competition will apply to the industry should ensure that the PSA's influence will, in practice, be limited to cases-likely to be isolated-involving abuse of market power.
The Australian aviation industry will also be fully exposed to the Trade Practices Act and its anti-competitive and consumer protection provisions.

A central issue concerning competition will be the ability of new entrants to gain access to appropriate terminal facilities at airports. A decision will be made within the next few days on the priorities to be assigned to individual operators for access to facilities located in Ansett and Australian Airlines existing terminals.

The FAC has acknowledged that it has a major role to facilitate operations by its customer airlines, existing or new. It welcomes additional business and will do its utmost to accommodate it in a responsible, commercial manner.

There will be a need to ensure that adequate information is available in a deregulated environment. In order to encourage a more competitive environment Governments, airlines, tourism bodies and consumers will need timely and relevant information on the aviation industry.

The Department of Transport and Communications is currently reviewing the information needs of a range of users in the deregulated environment to determine the most appropriate form, timing and distribution of information, along with appropriate cost recovery measures.

The Government acknowledges that access to foreign capital could make an important contribution to the Government's aim to open up the industry to competition. From October 1990, foreign investment will be welcomed, subject to the normal Foreign Investment Review Board Guidelines, including investment by foreign carriers which do not operate to Australia.

The only exclusion in current policy is unlimited investment in domestic airlines by foreign international carriers operating services to Australia. In such cases, the investment limit is 15 per cent in any one domestic airline.

The second major challenge facing the Government was to replace the outdated administrative arrangements so that the aviation facilities and infrastructure essential for a deregulated environment would be provided efficiently.

Accordingly, the Government took the significant decision to reform these areas by separating them from the bureaucracy. This was achieved through the establishment of the Federal Airports Corporation, with responsibility for major airports, and the Civil Aviation Authority, responsible for safety standards and day-to-day regulatory control of air service operations.
These new organisations, free from the constraints of the Government's annual budget cycles, provide the basis for a more efficient delivery of facilities and services.

The FAC was created in January 1988. Its primary function is to plan, develop and operate Australia's major airports. This has meant that, for the first time, Australia's airports have been placed on a truly commercial footing, with proper emphasis on their operating and commercial performance.
Adequate forward planning of airport facilities has been conspicuously absent in the past, and accounts in large measure for the problems of congestion and overcrowding at some of our major airports.

Nowhere is this reflected more acutely than in the capacity constraints of Sydney's KSA airport. Previous Government's had put the question of a second Sydney airport in the ``too hard'' basket. However, this Government has met this critical issue head-on and has taken decisive action to resolve the Sydney airport issue and to position Sydney to meet aviation needs well into the next century.

Whilst micro-economic reforms in provision of airports and terminals have already achieved visible results, improvements in the provision of modern and efficient air traffic services are of equal importance.

For this reason, and in recognition of the need for effective safety regulation and enforcement in a deregulated environment, the Government established on 1 July 1988 the Civil Aviation Authority. The Authority is responsible for both safety standards setting as well as day-to-day regulatory control, and also has operational responsibility for the provision of aviation services to the industry.
The Government was especially concerned when determining the functions of the CAA to ensure that the high levels of safety achieved to date were maintained and enhanced.

The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) is also maintaining its role to investigate and report on all aircraft accidents and incidents. In addition the Bureau prepares recommendations for increasing safety in aircraft operations and operates as an independent body responsible directly to the Minister.
Through a co-operative effort the Government, the CAA, BASI and industry are committed to maintaining Australia's excellent safety record.
Another issue that needed to be addressed by the Government was the implementation of measures to ensure the competitiveness of Australian Airlines.

Following incorporation of the airline in 1988 the new processes, announced as part of the reform package for the Transport and Communications GBEs in May 1988, will ensure that the Board and management have greater responsibility for the performance of the airline and are more clearly accountable for results.

Day to day controls over the airline's operations have been removed, including the requirements for Ministerial approval of contracts and expenditures, terms and conditions of borrowing and leasing arrangements, investment of surplus funds and the establishment of subsidiaries.
These reforms clearly placed the airline on a more commercial footing and will enable it to compete more effectively in a deregulated environment.

However, the Government recognises that Australia requires additional capital and is currently addressing a range of funding options which could meet the Airline's future capital needs without compromising public ownership and control.

A number of recent reports have identified areas of possible policy change including Qantas carrying domestic passengers, a single aviation market under CER, pricing of landing slots at KSA and major airports, and the level of foreign investment in domestic airlines.

In considering options, however, it is important to emphasise that any change to one facet of policy could have effects on other elements of the industry-there are many linkages and significant implications for existing and prospective players in the domestic and international aviation spheres. The Government will need to examine carefully the potential gains and losses.

The financial implications of the proposed deregulation legislation for the Commonwealth are minimal. As mentioned above, the Independent Air Fares Committee (IAFC) will be abolished. In the 1988-89 financial year the IAFC incurred $611 369 in running costs.
The Trade Practices Commission and the Prices Surveillance Authority will have an increased oversight role within the aviation industry.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1990, but the words spoken in this chamber and in the other place by our colleagues will long be forgotten while the impact of what has been decided this week lives on. I say that as a preface because this is not just another piece of legislation that we have to process. The Wool Tax Amendment Bills, in the strictest legal sense, will lift the present maximum tax levy on woolgrowers' returns from 10 per cent-in fact the actual payment by the woolgrowers was 8 per cent-to a maximum of 20 per cent. That is in essence what we are voting on in this chamber, but the ramifications of it are far more significant. In fact, Mitchell in the Australian this morning presents a very good summation of the whole situation. He has the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) standing beside an economist and the words are, `We've stuffed up everything else; let's stuff up the wool industry'. I hope that is not the case at the end of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: For those of us on the Opposition side, the decision we have before us is simple: either to accept the Government's offer of 20 per cent or to prevent its passage. For us the issue is not 25 per cent; it is not a debate about the floor price; it is not a question of the size or the merit of the stockpile. We have no amendment options. There can be no amendments. All we can hope to do if we reject the legislation here is to commit the industry to the status quo, a maximum of 10 per cent. That is not what they have asked for. For that reason we must accept what the Government has offered us and the industry.

For the same reason we cannot accept the Australian Democrats' amendment. In any event, I doubt that, given today's announcement of a drop in the floor price, woolgrowers would now want a tax of 25 per cent of their wool receipts. I think the events of the past few days have made this debate almost irrelevant. If we had any opportunity to argue for options to persuade the Government to follow another course, that opportunity is now past. The Federal Government has made its decision as to how it wants the wool industry to operate and we all-that is, woolgrowers, the industry and politicians-must live with it. I must state my pecuniary interests in the wool industry, as I run sheep myself for wool and for fat lambs.

I only hope, for everyone's sake, that the Government has this time got its formula right. In lowering the floor price, it may have set a dangerous precedent. How the Government and the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) sell this fall in the reserve to the wool markets of the world, particularly the wool cartels in Japan and Europe, will be critical to the future of the industry in Australia. It is very important that we all understand what it is we are debating here.

It is important that woolgrowers realise our limitations in this legislation, and that others who in recent days appear to have become instant authorities on the industry also understand the very narrow meaning of this levy amendment. There is no doubting the wool industry has some very serious problems, and some very difficult decisions to make. The present dilemna epitomises very clearly the cyclical nature of agriculture and the wool industry. It is at times a cruel cycle, and for many in the wool industry things are not good and they are likely to get worse. How quickly times change.

We can all be wise after the event and say that we all knew prices had to come back. Never in the history of wool marketing in this country has a boom period lasted more than season and a half. We could all look now at the size of the national flock and talk wisely of overproduction. We could all argue now that demand will fall. The prices paid for sheep by some growers and new investors into the industry 18 months ago were foolhardy, as it turned out. People knew then that the price levels could not be sustained, irrespective of other economic, political or meteorological factors. What could not be predicted was, firstly, the international political scene-I refer particularly to China, Russia and the eastern European situation-and, secondly, our own economic management problems.

We cannot isolate the problems in the wool industry and suggest that the position it is in is simply a result of its own efforts. Ahead of any other factor, the twin evils of the high interest rate regime that this Government has foisted on the Australian people and an inflated dollar value have had an enormous and, in fact, dominating influence. The full effect of these probably cannot reasonably be measured.

High interest rates affect the industry in a number of ways and at a number of levels. First, they impact on the liquidity position of the wool grower. Obviously, high interest rates affect a farmer who operates on an overdraft. But they also affect the farmer if he buys equipment on leases or hire purchase, or borrows against the expectation of a wool clip. They also affect the people who service one's farm. This is normal farm practice for many farmers and that is why sustained high interest, which everybody predicted would not and could not last, has forced growers into a financially impossible situation.

It is totally irresponsible to dismiss the interest rate issue as a minor issue, as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has done. It is argued that farmers benefited from high interest rates when wool prices were buoyant. They possibly did, but one good season does not wipe out a lifetime of debt. The fact is that high interest rates have been with us longer than high wool prices.

While there are many victims in this wool crisis, there is only one villain, and that is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. He, more than any other, has brought the wool industry to its knees. He has sought not to disagree with his Government's economic policies but rather to disagree with the industry. He has not apologised to growers for interest rates and dollar values that may well send them to the wall. Instead, he has blamed them for not making tough decisions and structuring their finances to cope. He has intervened in a market to induce a situation where the industry has been forced to accept a drop in the floor price. His remarks in recent weeks have been ill-timed and unwarranted. Growers will be a long time forgetting what the Minister has done to their industry simply, as it turns out, to accommodate his Government's economic mismanagement.

The Minister has accused growers of being unrealistic for failing to accept his predictions for their industry. But can we blame the growers? Take the 1989 outlook paper of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, remembering that ABARE has played a big part in the setting of the floor price and levy. The opening lines in ABARE's 1989 outlook paper The Future for Wool, read as follows:
While wool prices have receded from the record levels of last April, they are projected to remain relatively high into the 1990's.

That was only twelve months ago. So growers can be excused for making management decisions based on that fairly optimistic forecast. Growers can also be excused for not relying on ABARE's forecasts and advice this year. Given ABARE's track record, the industry is correct in its caution.

I would have had far more respect for the Minister had he kept out of the debate, waited until the end of the financial year and then undertaken negotiations with the industry. There is no disputing the fact that the market started to collapse and buyers started to withdraw as a result of the interventionist and disruptive comments of the Minister. I would frankly have had more respect for the Minister if, just once, he had acknowledged that his Government had got its arithmetic wrong-and did we not see that last night!-and that its economic policies were largely to blame for the wool industry's dilemma.

High interest rates have affected not only the growers but also the Australian Wool Corporation. The amount of wool that can be affordably stored is totally dependent on cost. At present interest levels it will cost $220 per year per bale alone to store wool, the bulk of which would go to interest costs.

There is nothing inherently wrong in stockpiling wool. The mining industry does it frequently in slow market periods. The question comes back to one of cost effectiveness. The cost of storage must influence the decision. If current predictions about the stockpile prove correct, interest costs alone would amount to $720m a year on a stock of four million bales and over $1 billion a year on a stock of six million bales.

The problems for the industry-and I stress they are the industry's problems-to resolve are: first, the issue of too much wool in store; secondly, whether Australia is producing too much wool and what should be done about reducing production; thirdly, the question of an appropriate reserve price for it; and fourthly, how to promote sales for the middle range wools and increase demand for wool, which in recent years has declined.

On the first issue, the size of the stockpile, it is academic to argue how much wool would have remained unsold this season had the floor price been lower. Had the price been lower or had there not been instability in the market over the reserve price, who is to say how the present sales might have proceeded. Market instability, as I have said, can be directly traced to Mr Kerin and also to Mr Keating and comments from people such as Senator Button, who dived into the debate by claiming that woolgrowers had failed to think sufficiently internationally and sufficiently intelligently about their industry. Those sorts of remarks have not done the industry or its standing in international markets much good.

On the second issue of too much production, it must be remembered that even in the best of selling seasons Australia has never cleared five million bales of wool, which is our current production figure. We have always had a carryover. The reasons we have such a large carryover at present are threefold: too much middle range micron wool from too many sheep; too high a price; and too high an Australian dollar value. That is the crux of the matter for the industry. There are those in the industry who insist that Australia can never have too many sheep, that we are the only country that can increase production. I, nevertheless, believe that for a variety of reasons, especially related to the attraction of a relatively high reserve price and some good prices, people moved into sheep, generally from marginal wheat-sheep areas. They now ought to be persuaded to move back to grains. But that also poses a problem as the Americans are about to have the third biggest crop on record, and the biggest since 1982; in fact, wheat could drop $20 a tonne. Growers could move to cattle, but that would pose a problem too with the overproduction of cattle. So stability in the wool market has always been a necessity because the other commodities move up and down without the stability of wool in the Australian market.

If we can reduce our sheep numbers and our wool production over the medium term, then we have a chance of restoring profitability to the market. I am sorry that the Government, so hell-bent on fiddling with the floor, fails to look at other options to reduce production. There has been little or nothing said about either a quota on production or a financial incentive to cull flocks. For example, if growers were paid $6 a head to cull aged ewes, and if we were to cull 10 million ewes this year, it would in effect mean 15 million fewer sheep next year. If we repeated that over a two-year period, our cumulative reduction would be close to 40 million sheep. The cost would be only $120m to the industry, but that would be cheaper than buying and storing wool from those sheep.

The other idea is a quota on production. I think it is the less attractive of the two options, but given that quotas have applied successfully in the grain and sugar industry, it ought to have been looked at. I am not saying that it should have been taken up, but I think it should have been looked at. Given the changes to and the potential collapse of the live sheep trade, it is evident that something must be done to provide a market or an incentive for people to cull their aged sheep. There must be an incentive to prevent them being kept for wool production. To date, nothing has been suggested for this end of the market.

I must make some remarks about the floor price, but I preface them by saying that there will be those who say it is the wrong decision, others who agree with it, and still others who do not know. The Opposition-the shadow Minister for Primary Industry in the other place, Bruce Lloyd; the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the other place, Tim Fischer; Dr Hewson; and everyone on this side-have said that the industry should decide on the floor. Even John Kerin said that in 1987. Again with the wisdom of hindsight, we can now suggest that the 870c floor was too high. Obviously a jump of 70 per cent over two seasons was too much. But the Corporation took the decision and growers and Government alike benefited from it. Little if any complaint was made at the time.

Whether it is now correct 12 months later to decide that the price was too high and ought to be lowered is debatable. I have heard the arguments from every direction. I have reviewed the compilation of statistics provided by the Wool Council and on paper and in theory the best, or perhaps the least objectionable, option for the industry-and in light of the fact that other options are not being offered-the only chance to clear the debt was to take a 20 per cent levy with a 700c floor. That was the package that the Wool Council put to the Minister and, if we look at the facts and figures, it looks the most palatable. The industry, through the AWC and the Wool Council, must accept its share of the blame for giving the Government that option in the first place if it was so untenable to them.

It is important to remember the impact of the 870c floor, or indeed any floor we set in Australia, on the industry. While we held a high floor and refused to sell below it, we were allowing other countries who could produce wool cheaper to clear their stocks at prices higher than they might have received had we not had a floor in Australia. Despite the acceptance of the 700c floor, I understand sources in the industry suggest that if the market stabilises quickly the figure is likely to settle around about 800 cents a kilogram mark.

I know that not everyone will agree with the 700c/20 per cent levy option. I do not much like the idea myself. But we have to accept that, for whatever reason, the industry has an expensive storage problem on its hands. I am less concerned about the size of the stockpile than I am about the cost of it. As I have already said, had the Minister not panicked-and panic the market he did-and had interest rates been lower, I doubt we would have had the dilemma we have today. Mr Kerin said he directed the Board of the Australian Wool Corporation to cut the floor price to 700c, saying that this was the first time in the 20-year history of the reserve price scheme that the floor price had been lowered and indicating that it would not be lowered again. He said:
My clear message to the market is that 700 cents is immutable.
He continued:
The next time the floor price will be changed is upward.

That is exactly how it will have to be. Setting the floor well below the expected level at the moment, which I have just said is about 800c-means it will never have to be lowered again. That has to be made clear to people all around the world in the wool industry. If we muck around with the floor price again, ever, the scheme that has been held in such high regard by so many in the wool industry all around the world will be finished.

However, it is no use talking in `whats' and `ifs'. Sadly, there will be many growers at the lower income end of the market who will be forced out. Across the entire wool industry there will be a slump because not only has their income been cut but so have their assets. The investment value of the stockpile is less; their land values will decline; there will be pressure on rural adjustment funds and there will need to be an increase in this year's level of funding of $36.9m.

I notice that Mr Kerin in a statement he is making in the other place this morning mentions the problems that he will have in that area. Mr Kerin also went on to say that he recognised that the cut in the floor price would create difficulties for wool producers, adding that the Government would be prepared to look at it. I think it is good that he is going to do that.

The fourth aspect-that of promotion-is a vital key to clearing the stockpile. Demand for wool has been declining for the past few years. Even Sir William Gunn is on record as suggesting that marketing holds the answers and wants more funds directed to the Interational Wool Secretariat. With wool's textile market share forecast to drop to 2.5 per cent over the next decade, better market strategies need to be considered, especially for middle range wools. A promotion as successful as the `cool wools' for superfine fleece would solve the industry's stockpile problems easily. Selling on terms might also be attractive to a cash-starved market and again this is another option that ought not to be discarded without discussion.

Another point that must be considered is that while essentially the debt is for wool growers, it is in Australia's best interests that the industry is not over- committed and unable to meet its own debts. Wool is a major export commodity; there is no argument about the important role it has played, and will continue to play, in the welfare of this nation. Often in this chamber I have said that we must all realise the debt we owe to the people of rural Australia who produce so much export income from which we obtain our standard of living. But it is for that reason that the industry cannot take decisions in isolation.

The wool-buying activities of the AWC are affecting the national savings, and long term they cannot be sustained or justified. When one considers the Corporation's worst case scenario of a $4 billion debt and a stockpile of six million bales, set against an industry that produces $6 billion worth of wool a year and purchases half of it itself, one starts to realise the appalling debt spiral that is potentially accumulating.

Given that high interest rates are a political and economic reality in Australia, at least in the short term, the wool industry, among others, has to learn to manage its operations within those constraints. The industry has to acknowledge that sheep numbers are up. Those in marginal wheat-sheep areas moved further into sheep when international wheat prices started to look shaky. Older sheep were kept when prices started to soar because it seemed the appropriate economic and management response to a rising market. With the changes and uncertainty in the live sheep trade there was not much other choice in any case, if one wanted to keep up profit margins. That cycle has now changed and it is now time to examine national flock numbers.

Perhaps in the next little while, parti-cularly if we get a dry spring or a tough summer, and prices remain depressed, we may well face a voluntary slaughter levy to pay growers to dispose of their older sheep. From a welfare point of view, we cannot allow a situation to develop where farmers can no longer afford to feed their sheep. This is a particular risk in marginal sheep areas that produce the middle range wools.

There is no doubt that the setting of a new floor and the passage of this levy Bill will bring some stability back into the market. But questions need to be answered. We still have four weeks of the selling season at the 870c a kilo floor. Does the industry stop sales, knowing that buyers are not likely to pay 870c when in three weeks time they can get it for 700c? What happens to those bales and what do growers do about their wool consignments between now and the new financial year? What will they do for a cash flow if the sales are suspended? What about the integrated industries which need a continuous flow of raw wool to keep their production lines operating? What happens to them if the sales are suspended? They have mills that have to be kept open if people are to keep their jobs.

In summary, this legislation is not a vote on a floor price. It is a vote on a 20 per cent levy. The argument about whether it should be higher or lower was never one for those of us on the Opposition side to make. It was only a case of whether it was 20 per cent or 10 per cent. We were asked to give a firm signal to the industry. We were assured that by not disputing this legislation and assuring a quick passage, the market would be better for it. On reflection, the industry has been put through a fairly painful extraction process. I can only hope that the industry now gets back to the job of growing and selling Australia's finest product.

I am encouraged by the manner in which Hugh Beggs accepted defeat the day before yesterday and his determination that the industry would `survive what it has been dealt. However, that by no means says that we condone the Government's action in respect of the wool industry. We abhor the mess that Labor's policies have meant for this industry and many others'. Mr Kerin will need to think very carefully next time he attempts to intervene in the market. He still maintains that he wants the industry to manage its own affairs. I hope that now he will leave it alone and let it do just that. I hope, too, that all growers in the future take more time to understand and observe what is happening in their industry. I do not believe that they have been well served by their leaders and they ought in the future to demand more information and expect greater accountability. I am looking forward to any legislation that will make the AWC more accountable at general meetings to the registered wool taxpayers. I also urge growers to remember their treatment at the hands of this Government. Their chance for revenge will come later.

The floor price has worked well for the industry and Australia and has given stability to a great exporting industry. As a very good friend of mine in the wool growing areas of the central west of New South Wales said yesterday, in the 47 years he has been growing wool, it is only in the last 19 years with the floor price that he has had any stability of income. He reflected that he had not made a great fortune during that time. That is what it is like on the land.

I accept the right of the Government to set a floor price. I conclude my remarks by quoting Mr Beggs, who said he accepted the legal basis of the decision and ruled out a legal challenge by the Corporation. He said:
I think we have to make sure there is no more speculation or division in the industry. Any further speculation can only be damaging.
He concluded by saying:
We do not have to pretend that we like it, but we do have to buckle down and make it work, and make it work we will.

As a person who has dealt with droughts, flooding rains, hailstorms and all the things that go with being on the land, I can say that the people of rural Australia will buckle down and make it work. However, it would have been a lot better if it had not been inflicted with the economic policies of the Hawke-Keating Labor Government, which have just about driven the farming communities of Australia to the grave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1990 which are before the Senate today and to make my feelings clear about the decision that was made by the Government to raise the levy to 20 per cent, but to drop the floor price of wool to 700c, when the industry was actually calling for a 25 per cent levy and the retention of the 870c floor price. We have just heard Senator Brownhill, a woolgrower himself, speak on this legislation. My family has no involvement in the wool industry, but as a National Party senator for nine years I have consistently travelled around Queensland and I know the vital part that the wool industry has played in the export earnings of Australia over many years.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to honourable senators that I truly believe that this issue should have been a matter for the wool industry itself and should have been decided and worked out by that industry. It should not be decided by a group of economists sitting back here in Canberra with some flawed economic theories. Economists have a very good track record of getting it wrong, and in this case they have got it very wrong. Unfortunately the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, and the Labor Government have followed their wrong advice.

Australia has ridden on the sheep's back for years. The wool industry over time has provided so much of our export earnings. It is Australia's greatest earner of export dollars. Ninety-nine per cent of Australian wool is Australian owned and 97 per cent of wool is exported. Wool has always helped Australia to pay its way. Now I believe it should be the Government's turn to assist the industry with its problems. But has it? No! The Government may think it is helping the industry by its action of dropping the floor price, but I say to honourable senators that all it is doing is helping to destroy the industry.

The marketing scheme has been great for the wool industry and for Australia. Our sometimes first and sometimes second largest export earner, the wool industry, has developed and made an enormous contribution to our export earnings. European and Japanese wool buying interests have disliked the success of our wool marketing scheme. They have not been able to manipulate the market and they have not benefited from the periodic collapse in price that was familiar prior to 1970 when the scheme was put in place. Now for 20 years the Australian wool industry has benefited from unprecedented price stability. But why, I ask honourable senators, does the industry find itself currently at loggerheads with the Government over the levy and the floor price? Unfortunately, the Government thinks that it has resolved it, but I do not agree.

The reason they have been at loggerheads is certainly not because wool has been surpassed as a fine material. Woolgrowers are not facing the situation where a synthetic fibre has been developed that can replicate the desirable and superior characteristics of wool, not at any price, let alone a comparable one. Confirmation of this is the fact that this season the latest available sales and export data for the eight months to 28 February 1990-honourable senators will notice the figures are not from the period when the Government suggested the wool price was going to come down-show that several traditional large and important wool buying countries with sophisticated and high technology processing industries have substantially increased their wool imports compared with the same period the previous year. West Germany increased its imports by 49 per cent; Italy by 9 per cent; the Netherlands by 377 per cent; the United Kingdom by 9 per cent and Taiwan by 19 per cent. But what has happened is that where countries have purchased significantly less wool, it has been agreed in most cases to be due to a shortage of foreign exchange currency, as in the Soviet Union, China and Poland.

The conclusions therefore must be that we are dealing with normal economic market forces of supply, demand and price. But nowhere have we seen the real truth stated as to why the Government is acting in this manner. I believe the real truth is that the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) borrowings are regarded by the Government as part of the Public Service borrowing requirements and that powerful elements of opinion in the Treasury and Department of Finance are arguing that these should be limited. Consequently, at a time when our foreign exchange situation is serious, the Government has undermined the AWC's authority and its marketing strategy. If the Government had speculated with the exchange rate in similar manner it would be accused of gross irresponsibility. We all know that the AWC's money and debt belongs to the grower, but this is somehow being ignored and I want to know why.

The Minister today in the other place is bringing down a statement regarding the fact that the Government is going to guarantee the borrowings raised by the Australian Wool Corporation before 1 July 1992 and interest on those borrowings. The Government has agreed to provide the guarantee as one of several measures concerning the reserve price for wool. I believe that in this instance the Government is trying to appease the Wool Corporation and the growers. If we accept that we are dealing with a fairly normal situation of supply, demand and price, as I indicated earlier in my speech, it is therefore absolutely imperative that the reserve price should have been held at the level of 870c per kg and that the levy should have been raised to 25 per cent as the industry requested.

I believe that the lowering of the floor price is both unnecessary and catastrophic for the scheme, its future operations and the orderly marketing of the Australian wool clip. The decision to intervene in the wool industry's marketing system has slashed $600m of growers' money off the value of wool that they own in stocks, $10 billion off the value of wool growing capital invested by wool growers, and around $500m off the value of wool held in stock by international processes, and it has cost the Australian economy a projected $3 billion in export earnings over the next five years. Those to me seem very sad figures indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —They certainly are.

—That is right, Senator Boswell. They are very bad. Nowhere has it been demonstrated, as distinct from asserted, that were the offered price for Australian wool to be lowered, there would be any kind of direct and significant demand response. Further, and more importantly, it has not been shown that any such response would ensure that gross income to the industry would increase or even be maintained. The industry's recommendations should have been accepted and not the Government's, because it is the woolgrowers who have a cash investment of more than $2 billion of their own money in the Australian Wool Corporation stockpiles; the government has none. Therefore, the action that the Government has taken to depreciate arbitrarily the value of these stocks without the formal agreement of a majority of the growers is iniquitous.

SPEECH.PARA: This interference could ruin the reserve price scheme and ravage future orderly wool marketing. Other consequences could be that textile buyers will turn away from wool to synthetics. It will cause massive long term damage to our trade figures leading to higher interest rates. It can lead to bankruptcies throughout Australia among woolgrowers and small businesses. I believe that many of the woolgrowers have been complaining about this decision that the Government has made, and ultimately it will lead to the loss, as I said before, of $2 billion in export earnings over five years.

I remind honourable senators that the market support fund, which is solely funded by growers, was not designed to prop up prices but, rather, to ensure a stable and regulated market to protect all parties, in particular the users, by giving them the confidence to expand their use of Australian wool. The decision of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, and the Government to reduce the floor price to 700c and raise the levy to 20 per cent will be disastrous to growers and users alike. We have to realise that the speculation about the floor price has done market damage that may not be recoverable. The slightest doubt and lack of resolution will only give the buyers encouragement to continue their resistance to the floor price. Does the Minister not realise that the wool buyers have not operated the auctions while the Government threatened to reduce the floor price to 700c? Sir Willian Gunn said: `If the price is reduced now it will destroy the wool industry's credibility. The reserve price scheme won't be worth the paper it is written on'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should know.

—He has been a very experienced man within the wool industry, and he must speak with a great deal of authority. It is up to the woolgrowers now to get out and sell their wool, whether by private enterprise or through their auctions. Whichever way they do it, they must try to get out so that at least they themselves will see that they are getting some income from outside, rather than just having their wool sold at the auction with the Corporation buying all the wool. Let me quote from an advertisement put out by the woolgrowers explaining their situation:

SPEECH.PARA: Retaining the floor price makes sense because the wool price today is the same as it was three years ago. Price is not a problem.

Our customers want a stable price more than a rock bottom price. The very people who buy our wool have pleaded with Australia not to drop the floor price as constant change in wool prices threatens their viability as well. They do not want a return to `the bad old days' of the 1960s either.

I heard of a country-I think it was Germany-which sent a message to say that because it had bought wool at 870c, if its competitors were going to be able to buy it at 700c that would put it at a disadvantage when it is selling. So we can look at it either way. I do not think it is a very good decision at all. The 870c floor price is in line with longer term trends. The Government's proposed 700c, in real terms, is close to the lowest ever price for wool. Wool is not a necessity and constitutes only 4 per cent of the textile market. If the Government makes the wrong decision, wool processors will be financially burnt and will turn to synthetics, rejecting Australian wool.

In meetings held in New South Wales and Queensland over the last couple of weeks, there have been unanimous decisions by the woolgrowers themselves to keep the floor price at 870c and to raise the levy to 25 per cent. It is my opinion that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, and the Government should have listened to the advice of the woolgrowers. After all, the levy asked for is to be paid by the wool growers themselves.

Let me remind honourable senators that the wool tax, which totally funds the stockpile and wool promotions, is paid by woolgrowers and not by the taxpayers. I ask the Senate: Why did the Government feel it necessary to take this matter out of the hands of the woolgrowers? Raw wool price has little effect on demand for wool. It had little effect in the late 1960s and the early 1970s before the reserve price scheme began-when prices fluctuated wildly.

The academic economists' approach to the current wool industry battle is badly flawed. When a conservative floor price was set five years ago, nobody claimed that they could see any significant difficulties. Now, suddenly, the Government economists are gifted with vision which enables them and the Minister, Mr Kerin, to see three, four and even five years ahead. To claim substance for such distant projection is clearly a nonsense. The wool industry comprises woolgrowers, brokers, buyers and our customers, the overseas woollen mills. Are the majority of these people irrational?

I refer to a letter which I cut out of the Australian Financial Review, signed by four Board members who were selected for the position on the basis of their financial, marketing or commercial expertise. They are Mr David Jones, the Deputy Chairman and Managing Director of the Fletcher Jones group; the Chairman of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation and former Chief Executive of H. J. Heinz Australia, Mr Ernest Barr; Nestle's Chairman, Mr Tony Whatmore--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not fly-by-night companies.

—No; they are people with marketing and commercial expertise. I believe that when they speak-and they believe that this lowering of the floor price and the raising of the levy is not the right thing to do-we should listen because they are certainly people who know what ought to be done. This action by the Government will certainly result in a loss of confidence in the wool industry if the Australian Wool Corporation is not careful. I believe these are people who are certainly interested in any actions which would lower the income of Australians, particularly the income and the future of woolgrowers.

SPEECH.PARA: When the vast majority of people in each of these areas was begging the Government to leave the floor price as it was, and to raise the levy to 25 per cent, should the Government have ignored them because of flawed economic theory? How could the Government possibly be acting in the national interest if it ignored the rational commercial judgment of the whole industry?

Finally, I would like to remind honourable senators of something which I find I have often expressed to this chamber-that is, that we should be ever vigilant that we do not allow ideology on economic issues and crass politics to misplace the needs of people. That is what is happening in many industries and it is being done at the expense of many important sections of our community. Today I believe it is happening in respect of the economic survival of Australia's wool industry.

I have a copy of an amendment to the Bill to be moved by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Senator Boswell), which will be circulated to honourable senators and which I will be supporting. I will not read it all because of its length. However, it condemns the Government for its arbitrary intervention in the mechanisms of establishing a floor price for the 1990-91 season. I think I should just say that as a direct result of this, the Government has undermined confidence in the existing floor price and forced the Australian Wool Corporation to increase substantially its purchases in the last series of sales; and it has ensured that the Corporation will have to increase further its purchases at the 870c floor price at sales up to the close of the 1989-90 season and on-sell to the trade at a lower floor price, resulting in a further cost to growers. This has resulted in the spontaneous downgrading of the Corporation's credit rating, thereby seriously further endangering the capacity of the Corporation to function on behalf of the Australian woolgrowers. Some further points are made in the amendment and I feel sure that Senator Boswell, when he speaks, will say something about them. I will be supporting the amendment which Senator Boswell will move on behalf of National Party senators. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are faced with an outrageous situation in this place today. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has, with a click of his fingers, nationalised the wool industry. Here we are, supposedly about to make an important decision on a set of Bills that are central to the future of the wool floor price, yet the Government has already determined what the floor price will be for the 1990 and the 1991 selling season. That in itself demonstrates a total disregard on the part of this Government for the democratic and parliamentary process of this country. More than that, it displays a total disregard for the role, the power and the independence of the Senate. That is a shameful attitude on the part of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: More important still is what the Government has unilaterally decided for the future of the wool floor price. For the first time in the 20 year history of the floor price scheme, the floor price will be cut. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, through his special powers, is bludgeoning his determination on the Australian and international wool industry, despite strong advice and recommendations to the contrary by the entire trade. The wool floor price scheme is now in tatters. Its credibility, its integrity, is totally shot to pieces.

The decision to cut the floor price is a devastating blow to the Australian wool industry-our greatest single industry. It will create chaos right through the wool and textile trade. The signal has now been sent out-where there is an oversupply problem in the wool market, the Australian floor price will be cut. This new Labor-imposed lower floor price can be cut again at any time the floor price scheme is down. To all intents and purposes, the floor price now is finished. The Government will rue this day. The Minister will go down in history as the man wholly and solely responsible for wrecking the greatest of all Australian rural industries.

If anyone believes that the setting of this new lower floor price is the start and finish of the matter then they are mistaken. There is no doubt that the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) will have to tighten its belt and get on with the job of selling wool and I know that Hugh Begg will do that. It has no option. It has that responsibility. I wish it well in its endeavours. It has been dealt a low blow by the Minister who has effectively told the wool industry that he has no confidence at all in it. I have confidence in it and in the people who work for it and who are appointed to its boards. I have confidence in Hugh Begg, the Chairman of the AWC, and in Chip Sawers, the Chairman of the Wool Council of Australia. I also have confidence in the wool industry. The growers of this country are prepared to stand behind their industry. If everyone on every side of the national and international wool trade-the growers, the buyers, the textile manufacturers, the international wool secretariat and the wool exporters-are prepared to stand behind the industry, which they are, in support of continuing the 870 cents floor price, who is the Minister to say that they are wrong? Why are the closet bureaucrats economists right and those directly involved in all aspects of the trade wrong? This industry has been worth to the Australian economy $6 billion annually in exports. For the past 16 years the industry has been stable and reliable, providing jobs directly and indirectly for 650,000 Australians. Why has this Minister been totally determined for weeks now to force down the floor price, to wreck this great industry? There is something crook in paradise.

The Wool Corporation and the Wool Council have presented to the Government a detailed case for the maintenance of the 870 cents floor price and for the increase in the wool tax levy from 10 per cent to a maximum of 25 per cent. These Bills are directly related to that proposal. The Government has said no to the 25 per cent levy and has instead determined that the levy should be set at 20 per cent, and the floor price cut to 700 cents. I say to the woolgrowers and the wool industry as a whole that it is a credit to the industry that it is prepared to accept an upper levy of 25 per cent to support the floor price. It is a credit that it is prepared at its own expense to make such a sacrifice in the interests of the industry and the country. It is a damnable shame, a total outrage, that others are not prepared to demonstrate equal faith. We are faced with an extraordinary situation.

The last three weeks have brought countless wool experts out of the closet. The Australian Bureau for Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) has been very specific in its predictions. While it would be foolish to have no faith in the Government's economic advisers, I believe that the people who best understand the wool industry are the participants, the people at the actual coal face. The economists can play the game on paper but the real market is moving and changing, and it is now played in the board rooms and in factories all around the world. I said yesterday that the determination of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Government to unilaterally force down the floor price is economic treason. I stand 100 per cent behind that view. This Government, and this Minister, have depreciated the value of Australia's greatest single export commodity by a staggering 20 per cent. If that is not economic treason, I do not know what is. Would the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, cut the price of motor cars by 20 per cent when the demand went off? No way in the world. It is usually the other way around. The price goes up or taxpayers' funding increases to prop up the industry.

Wool is Australia's greatest single industry. It supports itself and does not rely on taxpayers' subsidies. It has done more for the Australian economy and society than any other single industry. Wool is the only product in which Australia leads the world. It is Australia's biggest, and it is the world's best. Yet this Government has dumped it.

Let us look at the impact of the Government's action by forcing down the floor price. The Government has ensured an immediate loss of faith in the Wool Corporation's credit rating and a loss in export income to Australia of up to $3 billion over the next five years. There will also be a cut in the growers' incomes of up to $5 billion over the same period. There will be an immediate cut of $600m of growers' money off the value of the wool owned by them in the AWC; an immediate cut of $10 billion of the value of wool growing capital invested by growers; an immediate cut of $500m in the value of wool held and stocked by international processors; an immediate threat to the livelihoods of 650,000 Australians directly or indirectly dependent on the wool industry; an immediate and serious threat to the local economics of hundreds of rural communities which depend heavily on the wool industry for their very existence.

If that were not bad enough, the speculation directly caused by the public comments of Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) that the floor price should come down has cost growers at least $300m at wool sales since Easter. Corporation intervention in those sales was forced up from the low 30 per cent level in March to a staggering 90 per cent this week. That has cost growers $300m. It is entirely the fault of the Australian Labor Party and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, can take some of the blame. He had his hand on the till when it happened.

It does end there. There are about 500,000 bales of wool that will go to auction between now and 30 June. Obviously, with the floor price for the 1991 season set now-known to be set at 700c-no international buyers are going to come near the place. The Corporation will have to buy all of that wool an offer at the current minimum floor price of 870c a kilo and then on-sell to the trade at the lower 700c floor price. That will mean another loss of around $100m. The figures go on and on. We are not talking of a few thousand dollars here and a few thousand dollars there, we are talking about billions of dollars. It is not the Government's money. It is all growers' money.

That is one of the great tragedies. The growers are prepared to pay a higher wool levy than the Government will allow so as to ensure the integrity of the floor price. But no, the Government has got to shove its nose in and mess up the whole industry and socialise it. That is what this Government is about. It tells the industry, `No, you cannot increase the tax on yourself, even if you want to. Instead, we will intervene. We will wreck the floor price scheme for you for the first time in 20 years. We will depreciate the value of your product on world markets by 20 per cent and we will cost you hundreds of billions of dollars in lost income. So you should be grateful'. Senator Button said yesterday that the woolgrowers should be grateful. What a ridiculous statement. What an outrageous state of affairs.

This Government has totally rejected the wool industry's submission in support of the maintenance of the 870c floor price. For some reason the Government is absolutely determined to cut the floor price against all the best advice available.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't want their salaries cut.

—That is right. The Minister has been talking down the floor price for weeks. Now he has further devalued the close of season sales by actually setting the next season's floor price at the end of May instead of at the beginning of July. The Minister has single-handedly wiped off hundreds of millions of dollars from growers income and Australia's national economy. It is unbelievable and incredible.

SPEECH.PARA: Even the non-grower members of the AWC Board and Senator Bjelke-Petersen referred to those-men chosen specifically for their financial, marketing, and commercial expertise-are unanimous in their view that the floor price should be kept at 870c. They know what they are talking about. These people do not represent penny-ante companies. They are not fools. When it comes to product, price and marketing these people are highly successful in their own right. The managing director of Fletcher Jones and Staff Pty Ltd, one of Australia's biggest companies and one of the best suit manufacturers-I wear them all the time; the Chairman of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation, Ernest Barr; the Chairman of Nestle's Australia Ltd, Tony Whatmore; and the Managing Director of an investment bank, Bob Douglass, are all prominent and respected business people who have put their name on the line for an 870c floor price. So why is this Government so determined to dump the industry, especially given that up to the Easter break in sales there was every sign of the market improving.

Countries such as the United Kingdom, Italy, the Netherlands, Taiwan and West Germany were increasing their purchases. The amount of buying by the Corporation in the March quarter was down to between 20 and 30 per cent. The problems that existed in the market were not there because the floor price was too high. There is no evidence to support that at all. The problems predominantly existed because China, Russia and other Eastern bloc countries were having some types of exchange and reserve problems. For various reasons, Japan had cut its purchases by around 30 per cent compared to last season.

According to the President of the Wool Council of Australia, Chip Sawyer, who is now in Tokyo, the Japanese will need to buy wool within a week. They will probably have to buy it today or tomorrow. If they do not buy it today or tomorrow, the mills will close. The weavers will have to shut down. In other words, the Japanese are on the point of re-entering the market at 870 cents, and now such plans have been put in chaos. On top of these factors, as we know and as the industry accepts, we have seen a period of record production in Australia for the past three seasons-to 1,000 million kilos of wool. All these factors have combined to increase the difficulties for the industry, but they are not-I repeat, not-directly related in any way to the floor price and they were not foreseeable.

The industry believes that they are difficulties that can be overcome. Unfortunately, the Government does not share that view. It refuses to support the industry. The industry believes it can break into other markets and increase the overall demand for wool. This cannot happen overnight. No wool importer or spinning mill can flick a switch and take up the 2.5 million bales of wool that Australia has in stock. Factory production has to be planned; garments have to be designed; factory runs have to be programmed; and markets have to be fought for and won. It will require hard selling, promotion and research. That is the positive way: expand your market and hold your nerve. Anyone in the selling industry will tell us that.

This Government has panicked. It has dropped the floor price, restricted the levy to 20 per cent, planning a fire sale for quick clearance not of the Government's stock but of the Australian growers' stock. The Government, aided and abetted by the media, which seems to be the fount of all knowledge on matters relating to wool, has unilaterally determined that the floor price is too high. I wish the media would take its responsibilities seriously and not accept the line handed out by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin. Why do media representatives not stick their heads out the door and ask a few farmers about the situation? The International Wool Secretariat, which no doubt, according to the media and the Government, does not know what it is talking about, of the current floor price has said:
The current floor price in terms of major consuming countries is generally considered by the trade not to be a limiting factor in fibre choice.
The Secretariat further states:

There is no evidence that a modest reduction in the floor price would increase the demand, and a major reduction is unacceptable. It would mean a significant and immediate devaluation of the raw wool stocks as well as the stock of wool along the textile pipeline.

The 870c floor price was set two years ago. It is interesting to note that in 1987 the Minister for Primary Industry gave the industry the right to determine the floor price. When the industry determined the floor at 870c for the 1988-89 season the Minister did not complain. Did he complain when the floor was reconfirmed at 870c for 1989-90? He said not a word. Now he says that economic circumstances have changed, the floor is too high and the industry is being irresponsible for wanting to maintain it. The truth is that in real terms Australian wool today is almost 40 per cent cheaper than it was two years ago.

By undercutting the floor by 20 per cent the Government has effectively cut the real value of wool by 60 per cent compared to what it was two years ago. The international market has accepted the 870c floor. No-one has successfully proved that lowering the floor will result in substantially increased demand. No-one has substantially proved that the present level of the floor has caused a fall in demand. The Government has its priorities all wrong. It has listened to the advice of the economic bureaucrats rather than accepted the advice of the economic and commercial experts directly involved in the industry, both here and internationally.

We are now looking at a most extraordinary situation. The Government is going to bite the very hand that feeds it. Because of its shocking economic policies, the Government and Australia has come increasingly to depend on the foreign earnings of our great primary and resource industries, of which wool is an undeniable leader, to keep our economy afloat. Without commodities like wool this country would be totally broke. It is as simple as that. Yet the Government is now actively undermining the very viability of this great industry and is therefore further threatening the extremely fragile state of our economy.

If nothing else, the decision of this Government will destroy for all time the credibility of the floor price scheme and will cause immediate and dramatic chaos in many areas of the wool industry chain. Forward orders will be cancelled or have to be discounted, meaning that weaving mills, manufacturers and exporters will have their stocks devalued. Now that the floor price has been lowered, up to 50 per cent of our top customers could go bankrupt. The level of discounting and cancellations will be devastating as everyone in the middle of the wool pipeline will want some type of compensation. The 2.5 million bales of wool held in stock by the AWC will now have to be discounted. International buyers will be tempted to stay away from the market every time stocks build up, knowing that at any time this Government could cave in and refuse to support the floor. The wool market will experience dramatic swings in price. It will be like playing Russian roulette-the type of selling and buying that is in nobody's interest. Factories, weavers and spinning mills will not know what the next shipment will cost or whether their competitors will hit the market at the right time and leave them disadvantaged. Already, the private treaty wool merchants are facing problems. About half the nation's woolgrowers are facing immediate cuts of up to 50 per cent in their incomes.

It is not only the woolgrowers who have a stake in the industry, but the thousands of shearers who service it. Those are the people Government senators should be concerned about. No-one seems to give them a second thought in this Parliament. They have rightly shared in the prosperity of the industry, with better conditions and better awards. If graziers' incomes are cut, then this Government is not only putting the wool industry under pressure, but it is also placing under threat shearers' and truck drivers' hard-won conditions and awards and conditions. Entire local economies will be hit. Many rural towns are heavily dependent on the wool industry for their very existence. We are, simply and tragically, facing a grave situation here, which I am certain the Government has not fully appreciated.

I began by saying that we had been placed in an extraordinary position of having to debate a piece of legislation that is central to the future of the wool floor price, which has now been determined by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. It is an appalling situation. The Government is treating the Senate with total disregard. It should have brought on this set of Bills well before the determination of the wool floor price. It had plenty of time to do so. The Bills went through the House of Representatives two weeks ago. Why were these Bills not presented in the Senate earlier? The answer is that the Government does not care a jot for the wool industry, nor is it particularly keen on democratic and parliamentary processes. Weeks ago it determined that, come hell or high water, it would force down the floor price, and irrespective of the wishes of or submissions from the industry.

It will be to this Government's everlasting shame that it has not supported the wool industry. John Kerin will long be remembered as the Labor Minister who destroyed the credibility of the wool floor price scheme and who jeopardised the entire future of the wool industry, just as he did with the wheat industry. Beef producers should be quaking in fear to see what this Minister has in the pipeline to wreck their industry. They are next in line.

Mr Kerin, the Government, the bureaucrats and the academics should keep the score. They should let the wool industry and our other rural industries, the major money earners for Australia, play the game. They will regret this intervention until their dying day. I move:
At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate:
(a) condemns the Government for its arbitrary intervention in the mechanisms of establishing a floor price for the 1990-91 season, the direct result of which has:
(i) undermined confidence in the existing floor price and forced the Australian Wool Corporation to substantially increase its purchases in the last series of sales;

(ii) ensured that the Corporation will have to further increase its purchases at the 870 cents floor price at sales up to the close of the 1989-90 season and on-sell to the trade at a lower floor price resulting in a further cost to growers; and

(iii) resulted in the spontaneous downgrading of the Corporation's credit rating thereby seriously further endangering the capacity of the Corporation to function on behalf of Australian woolgrowers; and
(b) further condemns the Government for:
