TALK.START.PARA: —The Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1990, while they may be the last Bills that the Senate considers in this session, are probably amongst the most important. A number of speeches have already been made about these Bills in this place. I particularly refer to the speech by Senator Boswell, the Leader of the National Party in the Senate. It was a speech of passion and it outlined the enormity of what is happening in this legislation. But, more particularly, it outlined what has happened in recent weeks with regard to the wool industry in this country and the wool marketing system which was held in international high repute until now.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell's speech and the speeches by his National Party colleagues have been great speeches. They are important contributions to clarify what has happened. But Senator Boswell and his colleagues must realise that those speeches will be read in the context of the position which they have taken as members of the coalition. All that they have said about the scandalous approach of this Government, and the results of that scandalous approach in the demoralisation and destabilisation of Australia's greatest primary industry, is true, not just of the Government but of the Opposition. It is particularly scandalous that the coalition has buckled under to the very economic rationalist approach, which has motivated the Government's decision to press for and, finally, to act to lower the floor price for wool from 850c to 700c via its refusal to support the recommendations of the Australian Wool Council for a 25 per cent levy, which is what these tax Bills represent, and allow for a 25 per cent ceiling on a levy on wool growers.

By refusing that, and by bringing in legislation at 20 per cent several weeks ago, the Government signalled that it would have a lowering of the floor price. If the Australian Wool Corporation, the Wool Council of Australia and the responsible industry organisations and marketing organisations did not accommodate the Government it would, as it could under the Act, put forward, in the national interests, a reduction in that floor price. It was within the hands of the coalition to signal to the Government that that was unacceptable behaviour then, and not wait until it came into this chamber, after the fact, and to bemoan what has happened. If, like the Australian Democrats all those weeks ago, the Opposition had said no to Mr Kerin and had said that when the legislation got to the Senate where the coalition knew, because the Democrats had gone on record that we could refuse Mr Kerin's 20 per cent levy ceiling-we in this chamber could attach a request to these Bills that the House of Representatives reconsider and raise the levy ceiling to 25 per cent, as requested by the Council-if the coalition had accepted that responsibility on behalf of the industry, which the National Party members who spoke in this debate say they want to do, it could have been a completely different story and those speeches could have been made with full integrity. Instead the coalition made the decision to allow-

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: Senator Powell is impugning the motives and the virtues of honourable senators, and I would ask here to withdraw her comment.
—I do not think that Senator Powell was naming any particular senator. There is no point of order.

—As evidence of the sort of activity that went on a few weeks ago I refer to a letter which was distributed to coalition members in order to assist them in writing to angry primary producers and woolgrowers, in particular, to explain the coalition's position. The letter, which is something which is often done in political parties to help with the flood of mail when one section of the community gets justifiably angry, implies that the Opposition had no alternative. One of the paragraphs says:

SPEECH.PARA: The worst position for all sectors of the industry would be the possibility of the tax continuing at 10 per cent due to an impasse between the Senate and the Government.

The implication there is that we cannot act in the Senate because the Government might pull the legislation off. This is a common tactic in situations like this, particularly towards the end of session. Over this whole session we have been towards the end of the session-it having been only a four-week sitting in this place.

The story that the House of Representatives was sitting for only a week was swallowed, or at the very least was perpetuated out in the community, particularly amongst the wool industry, by an Opposition which clearly knew better, as we all did, than that this Senate would sit for four weeks. It would do its work and, if it chose to review legislation and amend legislation, then the House of Representatives would come back as it regularly does. Since the transport office knew that it was coming back, I would have thought that the Opposition knew it was coming back. The Opposition hid behind the Government's program of the sittings of the Parliament and did not put forward a genuine argument except that it believes and supports, as we have seen in so much legislation, the thrust of this Government.

I just want to make it clear at this point that the position of the Australian Democrats from the beginning on these Bills was, and still is, that the recommendation of the Wool Council of Australia for a 25 per cent maximum levy early in May, so that it could then make its decision with the Australian Wool Corporation about what the floor price would be, should have been supported and should have been put forward into this Parliament for legislation. If that had been done, then the speculation about the floor price would not have resulted in a withdrawal from the market of almost all buyers, that necessitating the Wool Corporation buying the vast bulk, in recent sales, of all that wool that has been on the market.
Instead, the Government made it clear that it challenged its own Wool Council and came forward with this particular legislation and, as I said, the Opposition acquiesced.
I now quote from the speech that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) made to the Wool Council conference in Roma on 23 May. He said:
In 1987 I gave the power to set the floor price to the Australian Wool Corporation after consultation with the Australian Wool Council.
He went on to say:

I made a mistake in believing the Corporation was strong enough to take purely commercial decisions about fundamental commercial issues, such as that level. I did not foresee the industry political pressure put on grower members of the board to push up the price. You will not doubt recall the NSW Farmers Association's demand for a 1,000c in 1988.
He said further:

With the benefit of hindsight, we all made a mistake in not understanding that flexible exchange rates mean that it is impossible to stabilise the price of wool both in Australia and user currencies. (You may have noted some spectacular corporate and public sector crashes in recent times that have been related to change in the structure of our economy and overblown entrepreneurship.)

In that speech Mr Kerin expresses his lack of support for the Wool Council of Australia and the Corporation. The Wool Council was set up by legislation of this Parliament only three years ago and, as I have said, it made its proper recommendations to the Government. We established the Wool Council of Australia-an independent body-to act in the interests of that industry. It is a mixed body of grower representation and of outside representation being people with business and commercial expertise.

Clearly, this Government does not have confidence in its own established marketing system. We actually find a great deal of difficulty in seeing any consistency in the Government's approach to its own statutory bodies. As my colleague Senator Bell pointed out earlier this week, there is some conflict in a response given by Senator Collins to a question about the proposal of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to take certain actions within its own operation. Senator Collins, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, said:
. . . if a statutory, independent national broadcaster is set up, it is expected that that broadcaster will operate with its own independent management which is responsible to its own board.
Further, he said:
. . . I would be very averse indeed to see any government of any political persuasion, as a matter of course, routinely interfering with decisions made by the ABC.
Further on, he said:

It is a case, I would have thought, for all of us . . . to wait until the Board determines, having considered what management wants to do and all the objections to it, what the programming decision will be. It is the Board's responsibility . . .

We find it quite strange that in that case the Government is prepared to stand by the independence of that statutory authority and yet in this case it is not prepared to stand behind this body, to accept its submissions and to provide it with the widest possible options-because that at the time was all it was. In fact, the Wool Council's submission to government-for which it was actually criticised by one of the speakers earlier in the debate-put a number of options, as quite appropriately it should have. It had not made its firm decision about the floor price. It was clear that there were options and everybody was still doing their calculations. To give it the widest possible options, it asked for a 25 per cent ceiling. This involves growers' money-as has already been pointed out-not taxpayers' money.

It was not that the Council was prepared just to take a shoot from the hip approach. Some of its members are directors with relevant qualifications who were appointed on the basis on their ability to make rational commercial judgments, people whose names have already been mentioned in this debate: Mr David Jones, the Deputy Chairman of the Wool Council and Managing Director of the Fletcher Jones group, the Chairman of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation and former Chief Executive of H. J. Heinz, Mr Ernest Barr, Nestles Australia Ltd Chairman Mr Tony Whatmore, and the Managing Director of investment bank Access International Pty Ltd Mr Bob Douglas. These people are conscious of their responsibility as members of the Wool Council who have been appointed for their marketing, financial and other special qualifications. Certainly in the case of Mr David Jones, as was evident in conversation with me earlier this week, he does not own a single sheep, although he uses a good deal of wool. They took considerable care to come to the best considered judgment they could. Very late in the piece, only early this week, they conveyed their final decision to the Minister as members making a commercial judgment. The Wool Council Board, in a letter to Mr Kerin said that its assessment was that it was very important to take a long term view and that the Government's expressed position-Mr Kerin's expressed position in Roma and in other places-was an incomplete interpretation of the past, present and future. It went on to point out that it is important in that exercise that the Wool Corporation, the responsible body, take on a long term stockholding role as one means of ensuring that past extravagances in the industry will not be repeated.

The Board's view is centred on the approach that there needs to be adopted a corporate and longer term view in developing policy strategies and plans for the Wool Corporation. It went on to expand its view that through the marketing system we have established in this country which, as I have already said, has a very positive international representation, our wool industry has been able to become part of the international fibre market and not just another rural commodity subject to wild swings of both supply and price. That is crucial to the long term future and to the ability of our industry to increase its share of the textile market. We have seen the downturns that have occurred as synthetics have become a much bigger part of the textile market internationally in recent decades. If the wool industry cannot, as the synthetic industry can on the world fibre scene, supply on demand-and people with business and commercial expertise point out that the just-in-time system which is now used widely in industry around the world means that supplies must be available with considerable speed as well as prices being reasonably well able to be anticipated-we must have a managed stockpile in this country. A letter from board members to Mr Kerin said:

In this way the Corporation can counteract the shorter wool pipelines of the customers which may well be the norm in the future because of the way business and industry operate, rather than simply a temporary phenomenon of the current record stockpile.

Those people did their figures and looked at what they thought was the realistic future. They pointed out that the stockpile would not be dramatically reduced very quickly but in their view many of the figures being bandied about were not accurate. On present indications, they said, the stockpile `would be well in excess of five million bales by the end of the 1981-82 season whatever the floor price'. They were writing to the Minister in an attempt to persuade him that the proposal of a 700c per kilogram floor price would not achieve a worthwhile result for either the industry or the economy.

The members raised in their letter the question of external borrowings. We have been seeing as part of this debate considerable discussion about the fears of a deficit blowout as part of the motivation for a cut in the expectations of the wool levy and finally a cut in floor price. In an article in the Australian of 17 May Paul Downey said:

The fear among senior economic ministers was that the balance of payments deficit would blow out under the impact of a $2 billion fall in wool sales combined with a potential $4 billion debt incurred by the Corporation.

That view has been fairly clearly put forward and is evident in the Government's operation here. The Government made this decision because it wants a quick injection into the national coffers to pull back the current account deficit.

It is rather staggering that it is one of our major national export industries that has to make this unfair contribution and to do so in the face of contrary recommendations by its own bodies-bodies set up by this Government to be responsible in the area. It has not been those high-flying entrepreneurs to whom Mr Kerin referred in the reference I made earlier who have had their external borrowings curtailed in recent years. It is the borrowings from overseas by private enterprise entrepreneurs, some of whom are in dire trouble, which have pushed up our current account deficit, our debt. They are now costing us almost $3 billion per year just in interest. The vast bulk of that is still coming out of the private sector. It is not those people who have been pulled up by this Government, but the woolgrowers of Australia on a short term proposition of a quick injection of funds. The Government wants those to come in at a lower price, using this as a brutal mechanism to restructure the industry. Fears have already been expressed about what might happen to other rural industries as a result of this crass way of doing things. When one has an industry which is prepared to restructure itself and to pay for that itself, there seems to be no justice and no rationality in the Government decision, certainly when one looks at the different way in which other statutory corporations have been treated by this Government.

The Government is clearly not behind this industry corporation. Instability in price and supply in the future will be the result of what we have seen over recent weeks. I reiterate that if this debate had occurred in a different context, one which could have been set by the coalition, and earlier, the pressure would have been on the Government to listen more closely to the industry and to do what the industry was asking it to do.

With regard to the context in which the industry is being hit, this morning in the Age there are figures which demonstrate that farmers in Australia and New Zealand receive less than 10 per cent of their income in government aid, payments and support, compared to 75 per cent in Japan, 38 per cent in the European Community and 27 per cent in the United States. Those figures are demonstrated by an Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development report which has just been released. We all know that primary producers in this country do not operate on a level playing field. It is in this context that the Government is thumbing its nose at the responsible bodies of the wool industry in order to achieve a short term benefit for itself.

The industry was prepared to levy itself and to build its own funds. It had top credit ratings available to it to undertake its own borrowings and it was totally prepared to take responsibility for itself. There has been Government interference in this exercise. I was fascinated to read an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review by a former Leader of the National Party of Australia. The debate in this chamber today might have been very different if the former Leader were here instead of the present Leader of the National Party of Australia (Senator Boswell), who made such a magnificent if irrelevant speech in the light of his position in the coalition. Former Senator John Stone, in his column in the Australian Financial Review yesterday, pointed out that it is not really only woolgrowers' money that was prepared to be put into the 25 per cent levy. He pointed out:

. . . the exclusion of the whole levy from taxable income now means that the Government's involvement in the process results in it . . . forgoing what would otherwise be a sizeable amount of revenue . . .

What a shame that that provision is a minor contribution to the 10 per cent of government type aid that our growers get compared to that received by primary producers elsewhere in the world. What about all the negative gearing that is available to all of those entrepreneurs who have put us in such a bad situation? I commend the cartoon in this morning's Australian to everyone as we debate this legislation. It shows a character who looks remarkably like the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) standing beside a farm fence with a gentleman carrying a bag marked `economist'. There are five sheep grazing in a rather lush paddock. The economist says to the gentleman who looks like Mr Hawke, `We've stuffed up everything else, let's stuff up the wool industry'. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

That is what the figures which the honourable senator points to represent. The Government anticipated that. Of course, we are concerned about it, but not surprised by it.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as the other part of the question is concerned, which I might say larded up the essential point, I only point to the national accounts figures published the day before yesterday and, I think, a general recognition that the Government strategy is on track. If those national accounts figures had shown a different picture two days ago, the honourable senator would have asked whether we are in a recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're almost saying that the policy is to increase unemployment.

—That is the old way. The policy is not to increase unemployment. The policy is to slow demand in the Australian economy. Inevitably, the marginal consequences of that have been recognised by the Government as a likely small increase in unemployment. That is what has happened.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Administrative Services. My question is prompted by a newspaper report concerning the owner of a Gold Coast chocolate company who is stated to have indicated that he will defy a Commonwealth Government directive telling him not to use the Commonwealth coat of arms on his chocolates. Is there anything to prohibit the Commonwealth coat of arms being used for commercial purposes? If not, will the Government give consideration to the matter of prohibition of use so that our coat of arms does not fall into disrepute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of background, I am informed that the Commonwealth coat of arms was granted to the Commonwealth Government by a royal warrant in 1912 and is used to signify Commonwealth Government authority and property. In response to the specific part of Senator Colston's question, there are currently no statutory sanctions in place to protect the arms. It has been preferred essentially to rely on community regard for respectful and dignified use of all national symbols. However, occasions do arise where private organisations use the arms without authorisation. When these instances are brought to the attention of the Government the organisations are formally approached, advised of the protocol surrounding the arms, and advised that their use is not in accordance with established practice.

ANSWER.PARA: This was in fact the procedure which was followed with Mr Garry Green, the owner of a Gold Coast chocolate company, to whom Senator Colston refers. On 10 April he was advised by my Department not to use the coat of arms on his products as it was not in accordance with the established practice. I gather from press reports I have seen that he intends to continue using it despite this advice.

In conclusion, a few weeks ago I asked the Awards and National Symbols Branch of my Department, the group which is responsible for monitoring the use of the Commonwealth coat of arms, to consider legislative provisions to protect the coat of arms against inappropriate use. I expect its advice on options available to government by the end of June and will take action thereafter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I draw his attention to the fact that in the first three months of this year Australia's foreign debt grew at the rate of $100m per working day, the great bulk of which was due to the need to finance Australia's continuing record balance of payments deficit. As servicing this record net debt of $123.6 billion now costs more than $1 billion per month and in view of the clear failure of the Government's policies to halt the continuing rapid rise in Australia's foreign debt, does the Government have any new proposals to correct the crisis situation its failed policies have produced?

—The Government, of course, is concerned at the level of foreign debt. The contributors to foreign debt include State governments, which owe approximately 15 per cent of that foreign debt, and that is an issue which I assume will be an agenda item at the forthcoming Premiers Conference; and statutory authorities, which owe 25 per cent of the foreign debt, and which I also assume will be a matter for discussion at the forthcoming Premiers Conference. The Commonwealth Government is now a net foreign currency creditor, making a negative 3 per cent contribution to that debt. In the Commonwealth situation, where we have enjoyed record surpluses in the last two years, the Commonwealth has, I think, played its part in dealing with the foreign debt issue. I can add nothing at this time to the references I have already made to the forthcoming Premiers Conference, but I will seek further details from the Treasurer in terms of any steps which might be taken.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his comments about new measures to be taken in his buck passing exercise against the State governments and statutory authorities. I ask him once again: What policies does he have to halt the continuing rapid rise in Australia's foreign debt where in fact the bulk of that debt lies, which is in the requirement to finance our continuing record balance of payments deficit which is officially expected by this Government to bring continuing rises in our foreign debt at a time when overseas interest rates are rising? If the Minister does have a view on what this increased servicing cost is going to be, what policies does the Government have to bring this situation to a much more satisfactory conclusion?

—We have been through this issue on a number of occasions in discussing the composition of the current account deficit. The Government's strategy is designed to increase export capacity, to increase the level of exports and, by lowering demand, to reduce the level of imports. That is the only way the current account deficit problem can be handled. That, of course, will take time, but that is the Government's strategy. If one looks at the national accounts figures published earlier in the week one will realise that that strategy is working, albeit slowly, in terms of the contribution of net exports in those figures. I can add nothing to that at this stage.

—I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to accidents and incidents overseas later in 1988 and early in 1989 involving the new Boeing 737-400 series aircraft and reported subsequent restrictions placed on engine thrust levels by civil aviation authorities. Are any Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) jet engine operating restrictions in force in Australia for the Boeing 737-400 aircraft operated by one of Australia's domestic airlines? Has any decision been made by Australian authorities to require the provision of smoke hoods in aircraft to protect those on board from toxic fumes in the event of fire?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know of Senator Maguire's continuing interest in these issues. He has asked a whole series of questions relating to the safety and integrity of Australian aircraft over a number of years. The answer is somewhat technical so I will ask honourable senators to bear with me. I have been provided with the following information: Boeing 737-400 aircraft are fitted with CFM 56-3C engines, which are similar to the engines fitted to the B737-300 aircraft but which are capable of producing higher thrust. Engine fan blade failures have occurred on a number of Boeing 737-400 aircraft, including the British Midland Airlines aircraft involved in an accident at Kegworth on 8 January 1989 which killed 47 people.

ANSWER.PARA: Technical analysis and testing since that accident have shown that fan blade failures occur due to vibration associated with the use of higher thrust levels than used on similar engines fitted to the Boeing 737-300 aircraft. The United States of America's Federal Aviation Administration has placed limitations on the use of the CFM 56 engines fitted to Boeing 737-400 aircraft which limits the thrust to be used in order to prevent occurrences of the vibration mode associated with the fan blade failures.

Senator Maguire will be pleased to know that the FAA limitations have been incorporated in the flight manual authorised by Australia's Civil Aviation Authority for use by Australian operators of Boeing 737-400 aircraft. Since introduction of the limitations referred to, there have been no occurrences world-wide of fan blade cracking or failures due to this cause. The effect of the thrust limitation is to reduce the payload of the aircraft on limited runways. This situation rarely occurs in Australia and the economic impact of these restrictions is therefore minimal. The reliability of all engines within the limitations now imposed meets all safety criteria.

With regard to Australian requirements for the provision of smoke hoods in aircraft to protect passengers from toxic fumes in the event of fire, I am advised by the CAA that the background to this matter relates to an aborted take-off of a Boeing 737 on 22 August 1985 at Manchester Airport after the disintegration of rotating engine components, which is an experience I hope that none of us will ever have. Although the aircraft was brought safely to a stop, the resulting fire prevented the evacuation of passengers from the aircraft and 54 people did not survive.

A recommendation of the accident investigation report was that the United Kingdom Civil Aviation Authority should urgently give consideration to the formulation of a requirement for the provision of smoke hoods and masks to afford passengers an effective level of protection during fires which produce a toxic environment within the aircraft cabin. The United Kingdom Authority accepted this recommendation and gave urgent consideration to the formulation of requirements for the design and provision of smoke hoods to passengers.

In December 1987, in the light of major collaborative research carried out by the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Canada and France, a decision was made by these countries in unison that a mandatory requirement for the carriage of smoke hoods could not be justified at that time. Nevertheless, the United Kingdom has continued with the completion of its specifications for a smoke hood, defining both the equipment performance and installation requirements. But, to date, no smoke hood has been shown to meet these standards.

In addition, the accident investigation report recommended that the proposed requirement for cabin crew smoke hood protection be extended to include training for crew, donning and use during aircraft emergency evacuations associated with a fire, and smoke threat during the evacuation. The Civil Aviation Authority has monitored developments in this area, along with other leading aviation regulatory authorities. On 20 December 1989, the Australian Civil Aviation Authority amended requirements for protective breathing equipment for flight crew members and required that on and after 1 January 1991 a pressurised aircraft engaged in passenger transport services must be equipped with protective breathing equipment units for use by the cabin attendants.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, relates to alleged interception and tapping by Telecom Australia of the private telephones of Telecom employees who make workers compensation claims in an attempt to gain evidence to discredit those claims. I ask the Minister: First, would the suspected making of a fraudulent workers compensation claim be classified as a class 2 offence under part VI of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 and, therefore, enable interception and tapping to be authorised? Secondly, what is involved in the procedure known as C-CASS; that is, the obtaining of a print-out of telephone numbers dialled from a private telephone? Is this regarded as interception under the Act? For what purpose may this procedure be authorised?
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. In so far as the question seeks a legal opinion, is it within the ambit of Standing Orders?
—Senator Baume has a legitimate point. I ask the Minister, in replying to the question, not to give a legal opinion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In general terms, telephone interception in Australia is regulated by a law of this Parliament, which requires that for an interception to be lawfully undertaken it must be done in accordance with a warrant obtained from a Federal Court judge. That is the only circumstance in which a law enforcement agency in Australia can undertake lawful interception of a telephone call. I seek Senator Bell's concurrence in providing him with a more detailed answer in relation to the claim he is making that Telecom has been intercepting telephone calls to check on the injury status of those who are seeking workers compensation. I think that was the general question. Under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act-this is only a very general statement; I am not talking about the particular instance that Senator Bell raised-telephone interception can be undertaken only to further investigate crime, not in order to see whether a civil claim, for example, is justified. That is a broad answer to the question. I will certainly seek further more detailed information to the first part of Senator Bell's question.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second part of the question, the particular type of activity to which he refers I believe is undertaken by Telecom in order to judge the quantum of telephone call time. For example, when a person complains that he has received a bill which is inordinately large in comparison with what he believes to have been the use of the telephone, a device can be attached to the telephone exchange somewhere, I guess, which enables Telecom to check on the duration of calls. It has nothing to do with the actual substance of the messages passing over the telephone line. I believe that a tracing machine of some description can be used in relation to claims of harassment, obscene calls or calls in which subscribers are threatened. I will seek further advice in relation to both parts of Senator Bell's question and provide him with an answer as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ISRAEL: PALESTINE LIBERATION ORGANISATION TERRORIST OPERATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Australian Government's attitude to the terrorist operation mounted against Israel yesterday? Will these events alter the Government's attitude towards the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that 16 Palestinian guerillas, in two speedboats, equipped with rockets, machine guns and anti-aircraft missiles, raided the Israeli coast yesterday. A Libyan ship is reported to have assisted in the attack. Fortunately, the attack was a complete failure, with four of the guerillas being killed and the remaining 12 being captured by Israeli security forces. No Israelis were killed.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government condemns this act of terrorism. It is a further blow to the peace efforts and clearly will harden Israeli attitudes. I understand that the member of the PLO executive committee, Abu Abbas, who is also the head of the Palestinian Liberation Front (PLF) has claimed responsibility for the operation. Abu Abbas is reported to have been responsible for the attack on the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro in 1985. The PLO leader, Yasser Arafat, has said that the PLO itself was not involved in the raid but his denial will scarcely be credible if he does not actually firmly dissociate the PLO mainstream from the group responsible for the operation.

I understand that the United States acknowledges that yesterday's attack was an act of terrorism and that Abu Abbas's PLF is part of the PLO. In consequence, the United States is examining its attitude towards its dialogue with the PLO which started after the PLO's chairman, Yasser Arafat, renounced terrorism, recognised Israel and accepted the United Nations Security Council's resolution No. 242 at Geneva in December of 1988.

The Australian Government reviewed its position on the PLO after Mr Arafat's Geneva statement. One of the main consequences was that the Palestine Information Office in Canberra was allowed to change its name to the PLO Office. In subsequent correspondence on this point with a PLO representative in Canberra, Mr Kazak, in February 1989, Senator Evans said:

The Government has welcomed the positive development of the PLO's approach to the peace process as expressed by Mr Arafat in Geneva and trusts that its commitments are pervasive and permanent. You will appreciate that any retreat from commitments in the future will necessarily result in a further review of the Australian Government's position. Our willingness to make the kind of gesture embodied in our acceptance of the renaming of our office is very much contingent on both the letter and the spirit of these commitments continuing to be observed.
Consistent with Senator Evans's comments, the Government will need to consider the implications of yesterday's attack and Mr Arafat's attitude towards it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce regard the collapse of consumer confidence to the lowest ever recorded by the Westpac-Melbourne Institute survey as, to use the Treasurer's words, another `beautiful set of numbers'? As nearly two-thirds of consumers are now depressed about the economy's long term prospects, the highest level in the survey's 17 years existence, and as this week's national income figures reveal a 13.5 per cent fall in investment by the private sector in new plant and equipment in the 12 months to March, can the Minister explain why these figures do not mean that Government policies are aimed at solving our economic crisis by destroying the viability of large parts of the domestic economy and increasing unemployment rather than building up prospects for Australia's export or import replacement industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already referred to the national accounts figures looked at over the last two quarters which show a net contribution to gross domestic product from exports and declining imports. Those figures are consistent with Government strategy and, indeed, the outcomes are consistent with government strategy. In the latter portion of the last calendar year the Government was asked a number of questions in the Senate about these issues and even the Budget projections. In answer to those questions the Government indicated that it thought that, for example, this situation would arise as a result of tight monetary policy.

ANSWER.PARA: I very much regret that consumer confidence, if it is correct, is the level which Senator Crichton-Browne points to in his question-that is, to use the words in his question, `not a beautiful number'. Nonetheless, the figures published on Tuesday show that the economy is still growing in excess of one per cent. I forget the other part of the honourable senator's question. I think it related to improving export performance and so on. Well, that is happening, unfortunately, at a slower rate than we would hope.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister tell me what significance he sees in the fall of 13.5 per cent in investment in private plant and equipment for Australia's future export prospects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures published last week indicated that, as a result of investment in calendar years 1988 and 1989, the productive capacity of the Australian economy had increased by 10 per cent. Those were the figures which, in a sense, comment on the results of the investment boom-if I can call it that-in those two years. It was anticipated that investment would fall off in this part of this year. That is happening. I think it is significant to look at where it is happening. The investment fall is not as high in manufacturing. I think the predictions about investment in manufacturing are actually quite reasonable. It is not a source of great comfort but, I think, if we look at the differential impacts of changed investment patterns on industries, we see that the mining sector is considerably down, but the manufacturing investment intentions remain reasonably strong. I said the other day that the investment picture is patchy. I do not retreat from that. I think that is a pattern which was anticipated.

ANSWER.PARA: Earlier in this Question Time, I was asked a question about the increase in unemployment in the month of May. I do not regard it as strictly relevant to Senator Crichton-Browne's question, but it has just been drawn to my attention that the Budget Papers anticipated an unemployment rate of 6.25 per cent at the end of the current financial year. This is up slightly from some monthly figures. This financial year, for example, the 6.5 per cent is down from the actual figure achieved in 1988-90 of 6.6 per cent. That is not a great variation. These figures were all before honourable senators in the Budget context, including predictions about investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Can the Minister advise whether an oil slick off the Victorian west coast has caused damage to beaches in the area? Does the Minister know which ship caused the oil slick? What action does the Government intend to take to further protect the beaches of Australia from oil slicks in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should make it clear to Senator Jones that the control of pollution from ships, especially oil spills, is in the hands of my colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, and not Mrs Kelly. Of course, when beaches are damaged-as they certainly were in this case-and quite a number of penguins are killed because of the oil spill, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories must maintain an interest. Certainly the damage has occurred and there has been, I think, the death of 75 penguins, as I read a couple of days ago. A number of ships have been identified as the possible source of the pollution. Officials of the Department of Transport and Communications have been to those ships and have taken some samples of their oil. Those officials are comparing it with the substances they have found on the beaches to see whether we can positively identify that ship.

ANSWER.PARA: Even if there is a positive identification, there remain some difficulties in terms of attempting to do something about it. The nationality of the ship and whether or not that ship's flag state is a party to the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships is going to be a problem. Of course, we must also establish whether or not the spill took place in waters of Australian jurisdiction. Any foreign vessel that is caught discharging in territorial waters can face a penalty of up to $250,000 for the owner or $50,000 for the master.

Oil spills are dealt with now under a plan called the National Plan to Combat Pollution of the Sea by Oil. The Commonwealth-State administrative arrangements provide that the primary responsibility for cleaning up beaches and foreshores rests with the relevant State government authority, usually a port authority. The Commonwealth Government will continue to work with the States to see whether we can prevent these oil spills. The Department of Transport and Communications will pursue this matter with vigour.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given that one of the central recommendations of the Garnaut report-that Australia phase out tariff protection by the end of the decade-was received by the Government with much acclaim, will the Minister explain, firstly, the concerns of Dr Blewett, as expressed in the Sydney Morning Herald today, that Australia should hold onto its tariffs and bargaining chips; and, secondly, whether the expression of dissent on tariff reduction by members of the Government, including Dr Blewett, is a sign that the Hawke Government is not capable of making the tough decisions and is tending away from deregulation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson can draw all sorts of extraordinary implications from Dr Blewett's comments if he likes, but they are extraordinary implications which he has sought to draw. Let us get the facts correct. The Garnaut report was commissioned by the Government. The Government has to respond formally to the Garnaut report and will be doing that in time. The issue of the reduction of tariff protection to zero by the year 2000, which I might say is Dr Garnaut's view, argued with some cogency, is never a view which has emanated from the Opposition or anybody else in terms of discussing the levels of tariff protection.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has had a steady commitment over its life to reduce tariff protection. I think the figure is something in the order of a 37 per cent reduction in tariff protection across the board by 1992 which, when put together with the Whitlam tariff reduction of 25 per cent in 1974, is a reduction of something in the order of the mid-sixties. I cannot do that sum on the last day of the sitting of the Senate; I cannot add those two figures together. It is something in the order of the mid-sixties. That is the only reduction in barrier protection which has taken place in the last 15 years. Nothing at all happened when the coalition was in government.

The Government is yet to determine future levels of tariff protection. The regime in respect of tariff protection until 1992 has been announced. The Government has yet to determine future levels of tariff protection post-1992. Whatever they are, they will be down. Industry knows this; the motor vehicle industry knows this, and so on. In respect of Dr Blewett's comment that the Government should hold on to the tariff levels as bargaining chips in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) round, with respect to my colleague, that is always a view which has emanated from trade Ministers involved in multilateral trade negotiations. When Doug Anthony was around he used to talk about holding on to bargaining chips in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round. The only thing that I can say happened with certainty is that nothing happened in terms of tariff reductions in the whole period of his life as a trade Minister. I do not know whether we ever cashed any chips in at all. Certainly Australia did not make much progress on tariffs in those years.

It may be that a reduction in tariffs, irrespective of bargaining chips and the GATT round, might be a useful end in itself in respect of the Australian economy, irrespective of any bargaining which might take place in GATT. That is a view which I basically subscribe to, but I do not necessarily agree with any formula about this. I think that there should be a pragmatic approach to it, which the Government has followed and I believe will continue to follow in the next few years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister noted that the Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister of Lithuania, Mr Katkas, described Gorbachev's treatment of Lithuania as that of an oppressor, and talked of fingers around the neck and Lithuania gasping for breath? Is the Minister aware that what is colloquially known as the Lithuanian embassy in Moscow has been visited by Moscovites just off the street apologising for the action of Gorbachev on Lithuania? Could the Minister tell the Senate what financial support has been given to the Landsbergis Government of Lithuanian people, and why cannot the Australian Government, since it does not recognise de jure the incorporation of Lithuania into the Soviet Union and in fact recognises the Landsbergis Government, give practical recognition by the appointment of a diplomatic representative to the Landsbergis Government?

—Senator Harradine has raised several issues, as to some of which I do not know the detail. Obviously I am not aware whether people are walking off the street in Moscow to voice support for the, as you say, Lithuanian embassy in Moscow. He has raised several policy matters. I shall refer them to Senator Gareth Evans on his return early next week and hope to give Senator Harradine a response. I am not in a position to answer those questions at the moment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given that in most cases the costs incurred in preparing environmental impact studies of major new developments are not tax deductable, does the Minister agree that the taxation law is lagging behind community concern and the requirements of government concerning environmental protection? Will the Government include this issue in the current review of taxation arrangements applying to mine site rehabilitation and removal of offshore petroleum platforms?

—The question contains a view, which I will communicate to the Treasurer. Inevitably, there is a degree of adhockery about these decisions. As a Government we have taken decisions in respect of recycling and some minor alterations to the tax regime in respect of recycling industries in some areas. I will convey the question to the Treasurer to see whether I can obtain an early answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Is it true that Kinhill Engineers Pty Ltd has engaged Thiess Constructions Pty Ltd as subconsultants to undertake the assessment of construction methods for the third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport (KSA)? Does Thiess Constructions Pty Ltd currently have a $5m contract with the Federal Airports Corporation for work on taxiway pavements at the airport? Can the Minister continue to guarantee the integrity of the environmental impact study (EIS) being conducted into the building of the third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of these further concerns that have been raised, principally in the Sydney area adjacent to the airport. These concerns show a continuing lack of understanding of how the EIS process operates. I confirm that Thiess has won a $5.4m contract on a competitive tender for taxiway pavements at KSA. For the sake of completeness, I mention that it has also been contracted to undertake pavement work at the domestic terminal at a value of $11m, and I am pleased to say that it is going to extend the apron at the international terminal at a value of $6m.

ANSWER.PARA: Thiess has been contracted by Kinhills to provide it, as the EIS consultants, with technical advice on the construction methods that could be used to build the third runway at Sydney Airport. I expect to hear a lot more about these continuing concerns prior to 31 July when the EIS draft is released. They show a substantial, fundamental lack of understanding about the EIS process. Kinhills is required to prepare a technically excellent document covering the fundamental question of building a third runway at Sydney Airport. Therefore, it has to draw, necessarily, on the widest possible advice and expertise to put that report together.

The reason that Kinhills has contracted Thiess to provide it with technical advice on constructing the third runway at Sydney Airport is that Thiess built the second runway-that is, the existing runway-at Sydney Airport. As a result, it would have more than an outside chance of knowing just a little about the technical problems of building runways at Sydney Airport. Frankly, I would have been amazed had Kinhills gone to anyone else for advice on constructing a runway at Sydney Airport other than this well-established Australian firm that has such an excellent record of construction. I am very familiar with a number of things that this company has built. I point out that Thiess is not the only contractor being used by the Federal Airports Corporation for works at Mascot. A number of other major construction companies have won competitive contracts for works at the airport.

I say in conclusion that the Government can guarantee the integrity of the EIS process. As I said in response to similar concerns raised during a previous Question Time, it is a very open process. The draft will be available on 31 July. The Government has made available the sum of $100,000 to interest groups to provide for technical examination of that draft when it comes out. A three-month period of examination will be provided in which the draft EIS and the processes behind its being put together will no doubt be put through the wringer. It is a rigorous process. The legislation provides for that, and the EIS will stand or fall on its own merits.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to his remarks during the committee stage of the Parliamentary Entitlements Bill when he said twice that he had `emphatic legal advice' that the postage money spent over $9,000 and up to $31,000 would be met by the Government or Australia Post. On 23 May, in answer to my question without notice, he said that he was obtaining further legal advice as to how to repay the overspent money. In a memorandum he sent to all parliamentarians last week he said:

QUESTION.PARA: For those Members of Parliament who have expended the full $9,000, there will be no entitlement for the remainder of this financial year. There is a possibility that the Commonwealth may need to recover any monies expended over $9,000. I will give you more information on this aspect following further legal advice.

Does he now mean that his emphatic advice that the Government or Australia Post would repay the overspending, in many cases by over $20,000, was incorrect? In light of this inconsistency could the Minister please explain why he apparently misled the Senate on 16 May?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first question of Senator Parer is no. As a consequence there is no need to answer the second.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister replied that the answer to the first question is no. That means nothing to people on this side or the other side of the chamber. I would also like to ask him why, quite deliberately, in the committee stage he used those words `emphatic advice' in an obvious attempt to sway the Australian Democrats and the independents to his line of thinking when voting on the Bill?

—I am sure that we do not expect that the independents or the Australian Democrats can be conned in the way that Senator Parer indicates. I do not think that I can add anything that would change any answer I gave either at the committee stage or in response to a question asked earlier this week, I think by Senator Knowles. In short, the answer to Senator Parer's first question was no. The second question does not apply. Thirdly, the processes involved in this have to be gone through fully and adequately and that is what has happened.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen the article in the Business Age of 31 May headed, `Australian industry fails to exploit the advances in research'. The article covers a report of the recent departmental document Opportunities in Advanced Materials. Can the Minister say what steps the Government will take to implement the recommendations of this report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article by Graeme O'Neill, who, I might say, is one of the most thoughtful commentators on science and technology matters and the relationships between science and technology and industry, has drawn attention to this report. If I might just refer briefly to some of the conclusions of the report, they are simply these: Australia has enormous natural comparative advantages because of an abundance and diversity of raw materials; we have a good research base in raw material applications; and that that has not been transferred into industrial development for a variety of reasons.

ANSWER.PARA: The report which Senator Crowley and the article referred to was commissioned by my Department and now that it is published it will be disseminated by the Department as widely as possible. It recommends that the Government should seek to focus attention in these areas: advanced ceramics; new polymers; biomaterials, and so on, rather than spread resources too thinly in research efforts. For example, generic technologies in new materials are the subject of the grants for the industrial research and development scheme, a designated area of that scheme. To try to assist diffusion of information about the competitive advantages which we might have in this area, a directory has been produced by the Department, Opportunities in Advanced Materials, which describes them and the associated processes in which Australia is believed to have advantages.

Advanced materials is also one of the four target areas in the key technology element of the metal based engineering program. The Australian Industry and Technology Council, which consists of myself and Ministers from the various States, has agreed to encourage the growth of advanced materials activities through the development of material application, testing and design centres and to encourage the establishment of advanced material user groups, company based demonstration programs and investment promotion.

In respect of those areas which are trying to bridge the link between the raw materials and the research capacity in relation to those raw materials and business, the Department will be conducting a series of seminars following on the publication of the report to which Senator Crowley referred.

In some minor respects the report is inevitably slightly out of date. For example, it is within my knowledge that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in the area of composite fibres is doing some important research work which is sponsored, and indeed paid for to a significant degree, by international aircraft manufacturing companies. So the quality of the research is recognised. —I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations to inform the Senate as to the extent of industrial accidents in Australia. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge Senator McKiernan's long interest in the field of industrial relations and, in particular, occupational health and safety for the Australian work force. One of the problems faced by researchers in the field of occupational health and safety is the paucity of information on the extent of industrial accidents in Australia. In recent times statistics on employment injuries and industrial accidents have been collected by each State branch of the Australian Bureau of Statistics with the exception of the State of Victoria. However, the collection of the information differs from State to State, with no national integrated standards.

ANSWER.PARA: This difference in standards primarily reflects the differing State legislation on industrial accidents. Nevertheless aggregation of State information, with the exception of Victoria, clearly shows that industrial accidents, along with personal and family trauma, have a profound effect on industrial activity. In 1986-87, the latest year that a comparison can be made between industrial accidents and industrial disputes, the five-State figure shows that industrial accidents caused 9.1 million working days lost compared with 757,100 working days lost from industrial disputes, a ratio of 12:1 in favour of accidents as opposed to disputes. That is an extremely significant level. It is extremely significant, too, in that most public debate is about disputes. There is very little public debate or examination about the cause of accidents and how to remove those causes from our community.

The Government has undertaken a number of programs to highlight the effects of industrial accidents in the workplace and to introduce safety standards in industry. Under the prices and incomes accord between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government, besides the restraint on wage increases that the agreement has delivered, there exists a comprehensive package for growth in the social wage which includes taxation reform, spending on health and social security, training, and occupational health and safety. The Occupational Health and Safety Commission, WorkSafe Australia, is the Government's vehicle to reduce the incidence and severity of occupational injury and disease and provide healthy, safe and productive working environments. WorkSafe's strategies centre on six priority areas: occupational back pain, noise-induced hearing loss, management of chemicals used at work, occupational skin disorders, occupational cancer and mechanical equipment injury.

WorkSafe is also directing its attentions to those anomalies in State statistical collections on employment injuries. WorkSafe has developed a national standards action plan in consultation with the States and expects that a nationally integrated set of statistical information on occupational accidents will be published next year for the 1989-90 financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs tell the Senate what action the Government has taken to enable consumers to be informed about whether any dolphins have been killed in catching the tuna that consumers wish to purchase?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only a week or so ago Greenpeace representatives called on me and indicated their concern about that, whilst tuna catches had increased greatly as a result of driftnet fishing, which was introduced in the late 1950, this was quite often at the cost of many dolphins being killed in the process. Honourable senators will be aware that circular purse seine nets, some up to three-quarters of a mile long, are in some waters set around entire herds of dolphins, then drawn closed at the bottom. Both dolphin and tuna are trapped and the air breathing dolphins suffocate and drown as they become entangled or are crushed as the catch is dumped on deck.

ANSWER.PARA: Given this situation, I have decided to invite members of a working party to establish a voluntary, industry-based code of conduct on tuna labelling. The objective is to establish a system of dolphin-safe labelling so that importers and Australian canners who sell tuna caught by methods other than driftnetting can identify their product to consumers. The working party will allow the commercial initiatives of the H. J. Heinz Company Australia Ltd, which already markets dolphin-safe canned tuna, to be built upon. It will seek ways to tap into international verification systems by gathering intelligence from the United States and other sources on the practices adopted by the fishing fleets of various supplier nations.

The working party will also examine the use of Australia's Trade Practices Act or other legislation to enforce the proposed code of conduct which, for example, provides for injunctions that may be obtained to restrain deceptive advertising. Even prosecutions with heavy penalties of up to $100,000 can be launched to ensure that no deception of consumers takes place. I have invited Greenpeace Australia, the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, the Food and Beverage Importers Association, H. J. Heinz Company Australia Ltd, Port Lincoln Tuna Processors Pty Ltd and the Tuna Boat Owners Association of Australia, together with various government agencies, to join the working party. I do not believe in centralised over-regulation in relation to consumer matters but I do believe that by unleashing consumer power in this area we can ensure that tuna fishing is conducted in a way which does not lead to the needless slaughter of dolphins.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week Senator Reynolds asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

The answer read as follows-

The Department does not have any special immigration programs to recruit doctors from overseas. Some doctors come to Australia under family and concessional migration categories. Others may be sponsored by hospitals under standard immigration requirements.

Hospitals may sponsor doctors for permanent entry under the Employer Nomination Scheme if they have not been able to find a suitable person within Australia. The scheme requires an employer to show (through advertising for example) that they have not been able to fill a vacant position from within Australia.

The nominee must also be under 55 years of age and have qualifications allowing immediate registration for practice in Australia. The employer must have a satisfactory record of training Australian residents and the position must be paid in accordance with Australian wages and conditions.
Similar provisions exist to sponsor doctors for temporary residence.

I am not aware of any ruling by the Department which excludes specialist staff needed by country hospitals. If hospitals can show that suitably qualified people are not available to do the work, they may recruit specialists from overseas.

Before the Department can approve doctors for entry, State Departments of Health must advise the Department whether the doctors' qualifications are acceptable for practice in Australia. State Departments of Health and the Department of Employment, Education and Training also need to advise the Department on labour market issues.
The Department is aware of shortages of doctors in certain specialist areas. But it is also aware that there is an oversupply of doctors in some metropolitan areas in Australia.

Shortages of doctors in country areas are occurring because doctors are generally unwilling to live there. I do not think that immigration is a long term solution to this problem. The Department cannot bind a migrant to one particular place after they have arrived in Australia.

The Departments of Employment, Education and Training and Community Services and Health are currently looking at ways to make the labour market more flexible. They are also looking at ways of bringing migrant doctors already in Australia into the system and persuading them to practice in the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today Senator Bell asked me a question concerning allegations that Telecom Australia had been asking some of its employees to intercept telephone conversations for the purposes of discrediting workers' compensation claims by its employees. At the time I promised a more detailed answer, which I am now able to provide. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
I am not aware of the allegations referred to by Senator Bell but they would cause me concern if they were true.

The interception of telephones is completely regulated in Australia by the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. The Act makes it unlawful for any person to intercept telephone calls without the knowledge of the person making the communication except where it is done by an officer of Telecom in the execution of his or her duties in certain specified circumstances, or under a warrant issued under the Act. Such a warrant may only be issued on an application by specified law enforcement agencies such as the AFP, NCA and the NSW and Victorian Police Forces for the purposes of the investigation of specified offences. Class 2 offences include serious fraud but only where the offence is punishable by at least 7 years imprisonment. A warrant is not available for the purposes of pursuing or defending civil actions or claims.

``C-CAS'', I have been advised, stands for ``call charge analysis system'' and involves the installing by Telecom of special equipment to record particulars of the use of a telephone service. These particulars include the volume of calls, the day, date and duration of calls, the numbers called, and registrations for local, STD and IDD calls. The equipment is used to check the accuracy of equipment which records information for the purposes of billing or to check usage in the event of a billing dispute with a customer, where an abnormally large bill is registered on a particular service or in the investigation by Telecom of possible offences against Part VIIb of the Crimes Act 1914. These include the making of offensive, menacing or harassing calls. The equipment does not record the content of conversations.

Technically, the use of this equipment by a Telecom employee may amount to an interception under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. Even so, it would not constitute an offence under the Act if it were done in the course of the employee's duties in connection with the operation of the telecommunications system or in order to identify or trace a person committing an offence under the Crimes Act of the nature just described.
I would also mention that unauthorised use of such information derived from it by a member of staff of Telecom could involve the commission of an offence.
