PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will amend the Wool Marketing Act 1987 to provide a Commonwealth Government guarantees on all borrowings raised by the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) before 1 July 1992 and interest on those borrowings.
The Government agreed to provide the guarantee as one of several measures concerning the reserve price scheme for wool.

The Government's guarantee provides a firm backing to the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) and reduces the risk of the financial sector reneging on loan agreements with the AWC. It will also assist the AWC to obtain access to credit on more favourable terms.

Mr President, Senators will be aware that yesterday the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy directed the AWC that the minimum market indicator reserve price for that year will be set at no more than 700 cents per kilogram clean.

The direction which the Minister issued is unprecedented. The guarantee of borrowings is similarly unprecedented. These two initiatives are intimately linked and it is therefore appropriate if I address the general circumstances prevailing in the wool industry in this second reading speech.
The Government's decision was not taken lightly.
It was taken after an exhaustive process of consultation with members of the Board of the AWC, with industry and with those involved in the processing and export of wool.
The wool industry is in a very serious situation. Demand has been very depressed over the past year and production has reached record levels. Prices have progressively moved down to the floor.

Corporation purchases have been very high during the year and stocks have now reached record levels. The chilling fact is that forecasts made by the professional staff of the AWC point to a further massive build up in stocks.
The Minister has been closely watching the increase in AWC stocks since last year.
However, because of the risks of altering market behaviour the Minister made no public comment on this issue until just recently.

Because of commercial hazard the Minister has been meeting with both the Chairman of the AWC and the leaders of the wool industry behind closed doors since late last year. In those meetings he emphasised his concerns about the prevailing market situation and the likely impact of this on the Corporation's activities.

Senators will be aware that late last year it was suggested that the Corporation would need an increase in the wool tax to a maximum rate of 15 per cent. More recently, it was obvious that 15 per cent would not be sufficient to fund the borrowing activities necessary to support a stock pile of unprecedented dimensions.
Automatically providing an increase in the tax rate to 25 per cent caused the Government considerable concern. Our concerns existed for a number of reasons:
We were unconvinced that by tackling supply alone that the industry would effectively manage the outlook into 1990-91.
We were concerned that the international demand for wool would worsen in the 1991 year.
We are apprehensive that this would result in additional borrowings by the Corporation and a level of stocks which could not be meaningfully managed in just a few short years.
We were dismayed at the prospect of a Corporation with potential liquidity problems being required, in the not too distant future, to act drastically to clear an overhang of stocks; and
We were concerned that growers were not fully informed about the risks associated with any of the options facing them.
On 3 May, the Minister met with representatives from the AWC and the Wool Council of Australia (WCA). The Minister advised them of the Government's concern.

The Minister next met with the AWC Board on 18 May. The purpose of the meeting was to hear presentations from the members of the Board and the Corporation's professional staff on their commercial, economic and market assessments.

His main concern was that all measures should be considered. That is, the reserve price, the wool tax, borrowing requirements and appropriate marketing strategies. The Minister required a complete package which would protect the future viability of the industry, and the long term interests of growers.

At Roma, the Minister conveyed a similar message to that which he had put to the Corporation earlier; namely to carefully and scrupulously examine the AWC's preferred option (which was a 25 per cent tax, a $4 billion borrowing limit and a floor of 870 cents per kilo), and compare the risks of this with a different set of measures.
The Government could not accept the AWC's preferred option because the risks to the industry and the Government appeared to be too great.
The risk goes beyond allowing the industry to bankrupt itself. In bankrupting itself, it breaks the backbone of Australia's farm sector.

With an 870 cents floor. AWC figures pointed to stocks of four to five million bales in a year's time. Two years out, the prospect was a full season's wool in stock. If demand fell further, say by five per cent, which is not unlikely given the situation in China, the USSR and Eastern Europe, the figures showed stocks at levels which would overhang the market into the late 1990's.
The costs of holding such stocks are enormous. Present stockholding costs are considered to be around $220 per bale per year.
Most of this is taken in interest charges.
The interest costs alone would amount to $720 million per year on a stockpile of four million bales.
If demand collapsed, then a stockpile of 6 million bales would be a real possibility.
That is not a wool mountain, that is a wool mountain range.
The interest costs of a stock pile of 6 million bales would be close to $1 billion per year.
Mr President, these figures give us all cold comfort.
These figures demonstrate that the returns to growers from holding massive stocks diminish at an extraordinary rate.
These figures demonstrate that commercial returns to growers are not maximised with stocks at those levels.
Given a 870 cent floor and given stocks of such dimensions the Corporation suggested that an upper borrowing limit of $4 billion would be required.
This would occur even with a 25 per cent wool tax.
Such borrowings by a statutory authority would set a new precedent.

They would act to increase pressure on domestic capital markets, increase our foreign debt and would result in interest rates remaining higher for a longer period of time than would otherwise be the case.
Senators will know that AWC's borrowings are currently approved at an upper limit of $2.5 billion. Given this limit, then it would be likely that the tax rate would rise beyond 25 percent.
If demand collapsed, then a tax rate of around 40 per cent would be a real possibility. The financial consequences for growers, the social costs to growers would be disastrous.

It was apparent after Roma that the AWC's and the industry's rock solid preference was for the 870c floor. This position was reached despite the presentations of AWC professionals. The Minister, therefore, arranged to meet with the AWC and the Wool Council on 25 May to discuss again a viable package of measures which would not jeopardise the industry's viability.

At this meeting the AWC put forward a new proposal based on a series of marketing initiatives. They considered that borrowings could be contained under the $2.5 billion, but a 25 per cent wool tax would be required over an extended period.
The Minister asked for this proposal to be thoroughly evaluated by his officials and the expert and professional staff of the Corporation.

The Minister also gave notice to the Corporation that he was considering issuing a Direction regarding the floor price. However, he made it clear that he wanted to see the evaluations of the AWC's proposal before taking a final decision. He advised the Corporation that he would be discussing the matter with Cabinet before any action was taken.
While the Government welcomed the effort put into the AWC's proposal, it was clear to him that it did not overcome the high risk of the 870 cents floor and 25 per cent tax option.
The proposal was based on sustained increases in trade clearances of wool at unprecedented levels. These exceeded the levels achieved between 1984-85 and 1987-88.
Simply, it meant a larger increase in clearances in the next six years than had occurred over the 40 years before 1986-87.
Mr President, I seek leave to table a graph which illustrates this point.

The House should note that the projections illustrated here are according to the AWC option which assumes increased demand resulting from promotional activities. Trade clearances are defined as total sales through the auction system.
Mr President, this was a period of extremely rapid growth in demand, highlighted by the strong presence of China in the market.
A marketing initiative does not, however, equate to firm orders. We could not afford to wait another year to see what prospects there were for increased sales.
The Minister's main difficulty with the proposal was that it did not get to the heart of the industry's present problems.

This simply relates to the basic economic forces of demand and supply. A price has been set at a level which has discouraged the consumption of wool in the face of competition with more price competitive substitute fibres. This has been particularly exacerbated by the foreign exchange problems of China and the USSR, two of our most important customers.

On the supply side, the price has encouraged an extraordinary increase in production. This increase has been boosted by an unusual run of good seasons. Shorn wool production has been at record levels in the past two years and these are likely to be exceeded again this year. The prospects of another record next year also looks strong. At the current price levels, growers will simply not cut back wool production.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics now tells us that we have five million more sheep than we previously thought. Our supply calculations have therefore been underestimated by five million sheep and the wool from five million sheep.
The industry, in general, accepts the 870c/kg floor was set at too ambitious a level. The increase in the floor since 1986-87 has been a massive 71 per cent.
If the floor had been set at a level consistent with the long term trend in wool prices then there would be no issue before us today.
However, had the floor been maintained at 870c per kg, speculation about a reduction would not have diminished.
Not this year.
Not next year.
Such speculation would have increased if the market deteriorated further. Under these circumstances, there is no logic in arguing that a correcting adjustment should not be made.

The Minister emphasised to the industry that an adjustment had to be made this year. At this time next year, with vastly expended stocks, the types of options available to us today would simply not be available.
Growers would have needed to pay whatever tax was necessary to meet the stockholding costs.
Alternatively the AWC would have had to go further into debt.
We would have been gambling with high risk stakes, namely the viability of one of our most important industries.

Another concern relates to the Reserve Price Scheme itself. In recent years, the minimum reserve price changed from a means of managing large unexpected downturns in prices to a price support mechanism. This development guarantees that the correct price signals are not transmitted to producers.
It also undercuts everything that the farm sector and the Government has been saying internationally on trade and agricultural reform.

We also have concerns that the proposal for the AWC to hold a substantial level of stocks, as part of their marketing strategy, departs from the original intent of the Scheme. The new proposal has connotations of an acquisition policy. A policy, I would add, rejected by the industry in the 1970's.
Such major changes away from the original policy or legislative intent must be subject to open review and debate before being implemented.

In addition the Government rejects any reliance on high tax rates for an extended period. With constrained AWC borrowing, growers could have faced the prospects of between 30 to 40 per cent of their wool receipts being taxed over a three to five year period.
It was often suggested to the Minister that this would discourage production and help bring the supply side under control.
However, it is senseless to not give a market signal to growers on price, but only give them one on the tax rate.

It is unacceptable, in our view, for Government to use taxing powers to force thousands of growers from the industry. When propositions such as this are raised I sometimes wonder whether it has been forgotten that Australia is a market economy.

Mr President, for the reasons I have given, it was necessary for the Minister to issue the direction to the Australian Wool Corporation to set and publish next season's reserve price at no more than 700 cents per kilogram clean.

The Government believes that at this level the competitiveness of wool will be restored and stocks, borrowings and the wool tax rate will be able to be brought down to manageable levels more quickly than under the present floor price. The risks of the financial collapse of the AWC or the industry are substantially lower.
Furthermore, the decision will restore the reserve price to its original purpose as a floor: to underwrite the market in order to protect growers against large sudden falls in wool prices.
In taking the decision to lower the floor, the Government will not contemplate, under any circumstances, further downward movement from this level.
The decision of 700 cents as a floor is immutable. The wool trade can now act with confidence that the price will not be reduced further.
The Government has given tangible expression in offering to guarantee all borrowings of the Australian Wool Corporation for the next two years.
Against this background, the Government has decided that a review of pricing policy in the wool industry should be conducted.

The basic aim of such a review would be to analyse changes which have taken place since the current arrangements were introduced in 1974 and to recommend measures to make the arrangements more effective. The Minister will be announcing details of the review at a later date.
Let me make this perfectly clear.
The Government's commitment to the 700c per kg floor is rock solid.
Any recommendations will not be allowed to induce another dizzy round of speculation.
Of critical importance now is for the AWC and the industry leaders to manage the future, for the sake of the future and for the long term benefit of growers.
The Minister acted with the greatest reluctance.
However, the Government, with the Corporation and with the Wool Council, intends to see the long term future of growers, and the wool industry secured.
Wool is of key importance to our rural economy and nationally.

It contributes approximately 25 per cent of the value of agricultural production. Prior to the recent contraction in demand it was our major export commodity contributing about $6 billion to our export income in 1988-89. This year its contribution is expected to be around $4 billion.

In facing up to the difficulties that lie ahead of the wool industry, the Government recognises the critical role of wool promotion. The Government accepts its responsibility to assist the Corporation in its promotion and marketing efforts, particularly the new initiatives which have been proposed.

Consequently, to boost the AWC's promotion funds, we will extend the Government's contribution to $75 million over three years from 1991-92. This will continue from the Government's current commitment of $25 million per annum which expires at the end of 1990-91.

The combination of a high wool tax and a cut in the minimum reserve price will reduce the gross proceeds to growers from wool in the coming season. Some small specialists who have few or no production alternatives will be hit hard.
However, growers' income need to be considered in the context of what has happened over the past ten years or so. And not just with the high incomes of the previous boom firmly in mind.
With a 700c per kg floor and a 20 per cent tax the average cash surplus earnt by wool growers in 1990-91 will still be above that earnt in 1986-87.
In fact, on average, it is projected to be as high as $15,000 above the cash surplus earnt by growers in 1986-87.
I would remind members that most wool farms only receive about 50 per cent of their incomes from wool-the balance is derived from activities like beef for which the present market is strong.

In making his decision to reduce the floor the Minister had to weigh up all the risks facing the industry and the short and long term costs and benefits. Had the Minister agreed to the 870c per kg-25 per cent proposal, then it is likely that this would have resulted in losses, over the longer term, of some $11,000 for every wool producing farm in this country.
In addition, by 1993-94 the share of the Corporation's debt attributable to each wool producing farm, as a result of the Corporation supporting an 870c per kg floor price, would be around $60,000.

Should the market worsen, and senators can assess the risks associated with the trade into Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union themselves, then the prospects for growers under an 870c per kg floor would be very bleak indeed.
And that is why, Mr President, the Government flatly and categorically rejects the concept of compensation.

At this moment, it is not possible to obtain a firm idea of the number of growers who might be affected by the lower floor and higher tax. I recognise however, that significant pressure may be placed on some individuals.
Therefore, the Government is prepared to review the supply of funds under the Rural Adjustment Scheme, including possible carry-on assistance and structural adjustment.

Mr President, the intent of the Wool Marketing Act is that the Minister should only use the power the Parliament has given him to direct the Corporation in exceptional circumstances. In legal terms this means that ordinarily the functions and powers of the AWC are to be exercised without Ministerial intervention.

I would like to take the opportunity here of reinforcing that intent. It was necessary for the Minister to intervene, in this case, because of exceptional circumstances, to ensure the future viability of the wool industry.
The Government hopes the need for such action will not arise again.

Over the seven years he has been responsible, the Minister's main goal has been to get the wool industry and, indeed other rural industries, to take responsibility for decision-making processes and to move these away from Government. His record on reforming statutory marketing arrangements since 1983 speaks for itself.
Despite the current events, we do not intend to back-track on what has been achieved in providing autonomy to the statutory marketing authorities, including the Australian Wool Corporation.

Mr President, in the past few weeks the wool industry and its leaders, the Board of the Australian Wool Corporation and the Government have been through an extraordinarily difficult period. The decisions that have now been taken have not been easy for any of us.
The Government is confident that the Board of the Australian Wool Corporation will be able to bring its best commercial expertise to the marketing of the massive stockpile of wool Australia has now.

Our first priority must be to send messages to our international markets that Australia is committed to the future of its wool industry and will stand firmly behind it. As part of this process, the Minister proposes to attend the 59th International Wool Conference of the International Wool Textile Organisation at Cavtat-Dubrovnik next week to convey this message to the world's processors of wool
He intends to convey this message, in the clearest possible terms, to the processors and manufacturers in Europe.
Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.

He said he was no Robinson Crusoe in terms of his misjudgment of the situation and blamed the experts for not giving him the right advice earlier. The coalition parties-the Liberal and National parties-have supported that view. We have supported that view notwithstanding our decision to accept the Bills that we are debating today-the Wool Tax Amendment Bills and the Wool Marketing Bill.

We have repeatedly argued that these decisions regarding an appropriate level for the wool tax and the floor price should be left to the industry. I am therefore very disappointed by the unwarranted attack on the Liberal and National parties in a statement yesterday by Mr Don Pfitzner, the President of the United Farmers and Stockowners of South Australia, which said he was:
. . . extremely critical of the federal coalition parties for their lack of support for Australian farmers in this debate.
Mr Pfitzner went on:

A substantial number of coalition members of parliament are elected from the rural electorates and they failed in their obligation to speak out and represent their electors in this debate, a point which would not be lost on rural communities in South Australia.

As one of those who seek faithfully to represent rural South Australians in this place, as a part owner of a wool producing property and as a current President of a United Farmers and Stockowners branch, I totally reject Mr Pfitzner's criticisms, not only on my own behalf but on behalf of my coalition colleagues.

I repeat that the coalition has repeatedly and strongly supported the right of the wool industry to manage its own affairs. However, in giving responsible consideration to the legislation before us it must be remembered that accepting a wool tax of 20 per cent rather than 25 per cent, which the sections of the industry sought, will not detract from the purchasing power of the Australian Wool Corporation. The present circumstances are adding some $200m a month to Australia's current account deficit. The wool industry therefore is in a state of crisis.

Despite my own regard and preference for wool as an apparel fibre, wool is not irreplaceable. The world's textiles, clothing and fashion industries are fickle and could be tempted to rely increasingly and perhaps irreversibly on synthetic fibres if wool is not reasonably price competitive. This country produces about 70 per cent of the world's textile wool and over the past two years there has been a dramatic drop in demand for it. We export about 96 per cent of our entire wool clip and the current stockpile purchased by the Australian Wool Corporation is worth about $2.9 billion. This is equal to about 15 per cent of the current account deficit or approximately two months' current account deficit. The wool industry is worth around $4 billion a year and wool is probably our most significant net export. It is of further significance for its research and development potential.

In the light of this situation and the criticism of the President of the United Farmers and Stockowners of South Australia, Mr Pfitzner, it should be understood that the coalition has no part in the price setting mechanism. That is undertaken by the Wool Council, the Wool Corporation and the Government and no-one else. The industry has therefore not provided the Opposition with much information, and when that information has been forthcoming it has sometimes changed. As an example, after its last executive meeting the Wool Council confirmed that a 15 per cent wool tax was adequate to meet the Australian Wool Corporation's financing requirements to maintain the floor price of 870c per kilo clean.

Figures which were provided for the coalition by the Corporation were unconvincing in many respects and raised many questions. These included whether the corporation would survive at 870c if there was to be a stockpile of five billion bales in 1995, and what borrowing arrangements were in place for a debt of $4 billion and above.

It is, of course, clear to those who look rationally at this issue that the setting of the reserve price two years ago at 870c was a mistake. That has even been acknowledged by a no more knowledgeable person with regard to the wool industry than my colleague from South Australia the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), a former Chairman of the Wool Council of Australia. That reserve price represented a near doubling of the reserve price in two years. The basic premise behind the establishment of the reserve price was broken in those sharp rises and woolgrowers, including members of my own family, have sadly paid the penalty and will continue to do so for some time

A number of factors have led the coalition to accept this legislation, which raises the wool tax from 10 per cent to 20 per cent. The first of those is that there appears to be little difference in the additional interest that will be required to finance the floor price between a 20 and a 25 per cent tax when one relates that interest to the total borrowings of the Corporation in any year. For 1990 the maximum added interest the Corporation would need to provide would be about $40m to $50m at the 20 per cent rate. If that tax were at the rate of 25 per cent, that $50m would be paid by the growers either in additional borrowings by those growers or in interest forgone.

Secondly, should the 25 per cent tax which sections of the industry sought have been sought by the coalition amending this legislation in this place with the support of the Democrats there was a real possibility of entering the forthcoming wool purchasing season with a 10 per cent maximum tax, because it is quite likely the Government would not have accepted that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—Face up to political reality, Senator Powell. The Government, quite likely, would not have accepted that amendment and would have let the legislation lapse; the present legislation providing for a 10 per cent tax would have remained in place, and it would have been untenable for the industry to have faced the forthcoming wool selling season in that situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, the Australian Wool Corporation's stockpile is currently some 2.5 million bales. This is expected to double to around five million bales in about 12 months' time. It costs about $220 per annum to store a bale of wool. This constitutes about $180 in interest and about $40 in storage. So, for every one million bales, we will be paying out around $170m to $190m in interest. This amount represents either the interest which one pays to an outsider or, if that money comes from the tax, interest forgone by woolgrowers. The present stockpile is already costing the Corporation $1.27m a day in interest repayments, lost earnings, storage and handling charges.

Fourthly, the value of a bale of wool dissipates totally inside four years at these interest rates. If the current rate of interest were a mere 9 per cent instead of 18 per cent, 10 per cent instead of 20 per cent, or even 8 per cent instead of 16 per cent, the borrowing requirement would stay the same but the interest to be paid would be reduced significantly. This is another area in which the Government stands condemned for its high interest rate policy and the impact that that has in a detrimental way on the wool industry.

Recent difficulties with the industry have prompted Hugh Beggs, the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, to maintain that the Corporation will continue to stockpile for another 12 months. Its stockpile is currently about 2.5 million bales, and this further stockpiling will swell to over five million bales.

The Australian Wool Corporation bought nearly 75 per cent of the 148,000 bales recently offered at sale. At last week's Adelaide sales the Wool Corporation purchased more than 87 per cent of the 21,885 bales on offer on the first day. It will be a tragedy if this country manages to stockpile over five million bales of premium grade wool, but it is quite within the realms of reason. As a result of that, in five years' time we may have between four million and six million bales still stockpiled.

It needs to be remembered that in the history of the woolgrowing industry in this country, going right back to the nineteenth century, extremely high prices have never been reflected for more than 1 3/4 seasons. That is a point that really needs reinforcing. Very high prices for wool always last for a only a relatively short period. The situation in which we have had relatively high prices for three seasons is a most unusual circumstance. In the 40 or so years between 1945 and 1986, the wool price fluctuated fairly wildly between about 40c per kilogram in 1945 to a high of some 400c per kilogram in 1986. The prices that have been achieved over the last two to three years and that have been reflected in the reserve price are significantly above that long term trend.

Originally the floor price was established for predictability, stability and the evening up of the price mechanism, which, it was then hoped, would advantage buyers and therefore give stability to the industry, and that benefit to buyers would then flow on to growers-something of a bad times insurance policy. It was not established to derive more income for growers, nor to compensate growers for their costs. It certainly was not put there as an incentive to produce more wool. The 870c per kilo price emerged from six years of rises in the floor price-an increase of some 50 per cent on the 1982-83 figures. Those who set this floor price ignored the ratio of the price of wool to the price of alternative products-in particular, synthetics-which blew out from three to one to in excess of eight to one.

Factors that are relevant to the current surplus are, firstly, that the industry never sells an entire season's wool crop in one year. Secondly, there has been a significant movement from the production of wheat to the production of wool in those areas in which it is possible to make that substitution because of unsatisfactory wheat prices over a number of years. Thirdly, there has been a continuation of excellent wool producing seasons, especially in New South Wales. Fourthly, there have been doubts about the return of China, Russian and eastern Europe to the wool market. Fifthly, there has been a considerable expansion in flock sizes as a result largely of the high floor price.

While the Government's intervention in this industry is unacceptable to the coalition, a realistic view, as I said earlier, is that 870c per kilo is too high as a floor price. It may be said that that is a judgment made in hindsight and that those who decided on the floor price at the time it was instituted should, therefore, not be overly condemned. But we really have to make decisions based on the present situation, and that situation is that we are losing our market share. Of course, we have only about 4 per cent of the world's fibre market. We are subsidising overseas growers. Despite producing only about one-third of the total wool, we are the ones responsible for providing that subsidy.

We are buying back half of our wool through the Wool Corporation. We are borrowing extraordinary amounts. The $1.8 billion which had been saved by the Wool Corporation in earlier years has gone and we have now borrowed more than an additional $1 billion.

The Government has used its powers under the legislation to intervene in setting the floor price and reduced it to 700c per kilogram, as well as limiting the wool tax to 20 per cent. Undoubtedly, this will hurt some wool growers, at least in the short term. But the most important thing now is to get on with the job of marketing more wool.

The International Wool Secretariat has developed proposals for expanding wool promotion to contribute to reducing the anticipated stockpile over the next five years. These proposals involve increased activity in western Europe, the United States and Asia-Japan, Korea and Taiwan in particular. The major proposed priority is to expand promotion of Woolmark products to the potentially higher volume middle market. This involves increased promotion of such end uses as men's and women's knitwear, men's trousers and women's skirts and trousers in the major markets.

The Australian Wool Corporation is also looking into ways to more aggressively market Australian wool. Such strategies need to go well beyond our present disposal strategies and efforts to develop new markets through joint projects in Italy, China and other countries with the International Wool Secretariat. There is also a desperate need to devote more resources to technology, to broaden the potential uses of wool and the way in which wool may be treated to make it suitable for a broader range of users.

The situation in which the wool industry is now left following the reduced floor price announced by the Minister is that the price competitiveness of wool should be recovered more quickly, improving demand, starting in 1990-91. A peak external debt of $2.1 billion should occur in 1991-92 and drop to zero by 1994-95. Shorn wool production should decline sharply in 1991-92. Peak stocks of just over 4.4 million bales in 1991-92 should decline to two million bales in 1994-95, thus allowing higher prices and with it higher producer incomes in subsequent years as a trade-off for the sharply declining wool grower incomes which will obviously occur in the early 1990s.

Offset against these comparative benefits of a drop in the floor price there are, of course, detrimental factors which must be considered. If the drop in the floor price results in reduced confidence in the floor price scheme in the long term, that would be of great concern. That will have to be monitored carefully. There may also be short term financial problems for some wool customers through devaluation of their stock. There will be, of course, losses to the market support fund through a writing down of the value of stock.

Given this Government's intervention, it is therefore even more incumbent on the Government to minimise the impact of this potential downside for woolgrowers. This can be done only by a significant change in economic policy and management to create a better economic environment within which export industries, particularly the wool industry, can operate. Labor's policies of high interest rates and high inflation, which have appreciated our exchange rate, have been the most significant reason why Australia's major industry, the wool industry, has had difficulty in competing against the textile fibre industries in other countries, where interest rates and inflation are much lower. How can any exporter compete with countries which have interest rates and inflation at less than half of those which we have to live under this Hawke Labor Government in Australia? Instead of relying on failed policies, the Government should get on with the job of restructuring the labour market, freeing up the labour market, establish an enterprise based union structure, clean up the waterfront, inject some competition into coastal shipping and obtain substantial improvements in road and rail transport as well as getting rid of tariff protection, the costs of which are borne by exporters in general and, more particularly, by rural producers. Let us have no more of Senator Button dragging the chain as far as tariff reductions are concerned.

We did have a promise from the Government that it would get stuck into these areas when it deregulated the domestic wheat market and we are still waiting for those deregulatory decisions to be implemented. This Government simply drags the chain and stays out on one long smoko when it comes to dealing with its own mates in the union movement who benefit from these closed shops and uncompetitive situations. In direct contrast to this, of course, the coalition has adopted firm policies in these areas and accorded them the highest priority. Of course, we will not have the opportunity to implement those for some three years. Action is required far more urgently than that. So it is incumbent on this Government to initiate that action. But, as we have seen and as I have just remarked, the past record of the Government in this area really indicates that it lacks the willpower to implement these much needed reforms.

In conclusion, I urge the Government to get on with the business of implementing those reforms so that the wool industry can salvage its situation from the present crisis and go forward with confidence in the 1990s.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, this is a very sad day for us, for it is a day on which we have to recognise that our most famous industry, and our greatest export earner, the wool industry, is in serious difficulties through the gross mishandling of its affairs by the Australian Wool Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of this Corporation still do not seem to recognise their extraordinary incompetence, which bodes ill for the future because our wool will need very sensible handling over the next few years if we are to restore its credibility.

The tragedy of the wool crisis is that it has gripped perhaps the one industry where Australia can justifiably claim to be the world leader. Australian merinos produce some of the best and lowest-cost wool available. Backed with the highly successful Woolmark campaigns, the industry has met competition from synthetic fibres and continued to contribute heavily to the export effort.

I saw a statement from the Chairman of the Wool Corporation referring to the Corporation's advice being over-ridden by, as he expressed it, `a bunch of bureaucrats and purist economists with little or no commercial or marketing experience'. One could wish that the Wool Corporation had a little elementary economic knowledge, particularly in areas such as the law of supply and demand, the probability of substitution if prices of a commodity become excessive, and the importance of not distorting market signals. I am afraid the Wool Corporation will be abject failures in all of these.

There seems to me to have been more nonsense talked in this whole debate in the wool community than I have heard in modern times. Let us establish a few important parameters. The first is that the wool industry is not homogeneous. The superfine wool producers, who produce about 5 per cent of the clip, have been selling their wool well above the floor price. At the other end of the spectrum, the carpet wool growers, using mainly New Zealand sheep, have been operating profitably at about half the floor price. They do not get the floor price because they sell to the local carpet manufacturers. If they attempted to get the floor price, defying the law of supply and demand, the carpet manufacturers would merely shift to New Zealand wool.

The behaviour of the Wool Corporation, however, is likely to push them out of the industry. Although they are profitable at present, if the levy is pushed up to 20 per cent as proposed in these Wool Tax Amendment Bills, or 25 per cent, as wanted by the Wool Corporation, many of them would go out of business because they would cease to be profitable.

The greatest problem area, of course, is in strong wool-22 microns and upwards. There can be no doubt that the price we are asking for this wool is more than the market is prepared to pay. Although we are substantial suppliers of wool-70 per cent of the world's textile wool-we do not have a monopoly. Our competitors-the South Africans, the New Zealanders and the Argentineans-are laughing all the way to the bank while this nonsense goes on from the Australian Wool Corporation. All the remarks from the Australian Wool Corporation echo similar remarks made during similar failed attempts to manipulate commodity markets by cartels-the coffee market, the tin market, the cocoa market; you name them. The only body able to operate in the way the Australian Wool Corporation wants to operate is in the diamond market, because there it is very easy to control supply and to store the commodity. With wool, it is not easy to control supply in the short term. Worse still, the Wool Corporation is sending all the wrong signals to the growers of wool which we cannot sell at the price we are asking. The message is: `Produce more wool and we will buy it from you at an excellent price'. The result, inevitably, has been a sharp rise in sheep numbers. We tamper with the market mechanism at our peril. Eastern Europe seems to be waking up to this; it is about time the Wool Corporation did.

Now, Madam Acting Deputy President, let us look at the levy. This is based on the gross income of wool growers. It was set at 8 per cent, which I think was a justifiable figure. Of course, the levy was used for wool promotion and eliminating potholes at wool sales-that is, attempts by cliques of buyers to manipulate the price, or the temporary absence of buyers. If it was not needed it was returned to the growers. What it was never intended to do, and what it never could do, was to hold the wool price above what the market would bear. What happened was that there was a sudden rise between 1986-87, 1988-89, when wool prices went up by about 70 per cent. For comparison, the rise over the previous of 10 years had been 39 per cent. Over 10 years it has been 39 per cent; it then went up by 70 per cent in two years.

Incidentally, this brings up another argument about the floor price-that it achieves a stability in wool price which is important both to growers and to customers. In fact, it does no such thing. It maintains a minimum price but it does nothing-it can and should do nothing-about maximum price. The sudden rise in the price of wool as in 1987-88 are very disturbing for wool users, and push them towards the use of alternatives such as cotton and synthetics. From being between two and three times more expensive than cotton and synthetics, wool suddenly shot up to five times as expensive. This drives users out of wool, and once driven out they do not soon return.

The trouble was that when the price went up by 70 per cent, the floor price went up too, despite the fact that the sudden spurt of demand was not, and could not be expected to be, sustained. Worse still, the Wool Corporation does not seem to understand that overseas buyers do not think in Australian dollars. They think either in their own currency or in United States dollars. The rise in the Australian dollar against the US dollar and most other currencies effectively caused the floor price to rise still further while demand was falling. I think the Wool Corporation should do some Year 11 economics.

It is not going to be easy to get out of this Wool Corporation induced mess. Cartels are always dangerous things for an economy and an incompetent cartel is even worse. I personally would like to see the levy left at 8 per cent. This seems to me to be plenty for the proper functions of the Wool Corporation. Nevertheless, it has got this enormous stockpile which will take considerable time to clear, and it is worth remembering that because of interest and storage charges the net value of stored wool falls by about 25 per cent a year. In other words, its value disappears after four years.

We have got to sacrifice ourselves, our national economy and, regrettably, penalise the woolgrowers in order to get out of this Wool Corporation created mess. For that reason I am prepared to support the 20 per cent levy on the wool clip, though this will do serious damage to the carpet wool growers. I will also support the increase in the Wool Corporation's borrowing limits. However, I wish the Wool Corporation would stop this bombastic nonsense which is irresistibly reminiscent of Alan Bond, Christopher Skase, Laurie Connell and all the others-`Just let's borrow a few more billion dollars, and all will be well'.

I hope all of its members will have the decency to resign and be replaced by more competent people. In the meantime, though, we must do all we can to sort out the mess. Our woolgrowers are highly efficient. Our primary producers are probably, per capita, the most productive in the world. They deserve better management and leadership than has been provided by the Australian Wool Corporation. By the way, Madam Acting Deputy President, I am a superfine woolgrower.

Further, not only has the industry faced a dollar value write-down of its stockpile to a tune of billions of dollars but the industry will now suffer massive losses in asset values at the farm gate.
I wish to refer to a letter to the editor of the Australian which produces reliable calculations regarding this matter. The letter, from Doug Anthony, reads:

When the Wool Commission was first proposed in the 1960s it faced strong opposition from international wool buyers. In the first year of the Wool Commission's operation, it was challenged by foreign buying interests. The funds then made available to support the reserve price were soon exhausted and more funds were needed.

It became a major issue for the then government (the McMahon/Anthony government). The issue was hotly debated and nearly split the Coalition government. Fortunately, Prime Minister McMahon and Treasurer Sneddon reluctantly agreed to provide an additional $50 million and from that day on the corporation has been able to hold the line on the reserve price.

I am convinced that now world creditors have seen that our premier export product is losing its value and is subject to wild price fluctuations, a loss of confidence will not only occur in the wool industry, but flow on to other export industries.
This will further downgrade our nation's credit rating.

I wish now to turn to the supply side of the argument. Taking the wild assumption used by economists that ``all things being constant''-though on the land that is never the case-the ABARE paper forecasts for 1990-91 season that the number of shorn sheep will increase by 2 million to 215 million.
It is simply argued that this number is an oversupply of wool on the market that is contributing to a downward pressure on prices.
However, on closer analysis this is not the case.
Firstly: the 2 million increase is a small number of the total. It represents only a 1% increase in production in Australia.
In world terms the ABARE March quarterly statistics report that the 1988-89 season saw a 3% increase.
In 1989-90 production stabilised and for the 1990-91 world production is predicted to remain much the same at 1.9 million tonnes.
In essence world production has plateaued.
It is estimated after the 1990-91 season in Australia, domestic production will plateau and decline.
The ABARE March quarterly reports that demand for Australian wool in 1989-90 fell 27% while production rose 13%.
In 1990/91 year it is estimated that demand will increase 27% and supply only 1%.
That means the Australian supply of wool has already started to adjust to the market. As the 1% increase shows.
It should be added in practical terms Australia only has so many paddocks and so much feed.

Further to this, due to the uncertainty that has now engulfed the market, those fringe growers that entered to capture the record prices and could not work to the floor of 870, would have to move out of wool production.
While this number is difficult to quantify it still remains an effect on supply.
Now the Government's decision will devastate all wool growers.
It is believed by the abare economists that an increase in the levy to 25% is not as an effective market signal to reduce supply.
I quote ` . . . growers can reasonably be expected to interpret an increase in the tax without any adjustment to the floor as an indication that the present situation is only short term in nature.'
I strongly disagree with this statement.
It is a strong market signal to take a quarter of a grower's income.
It also misses a fundamental point in the raising of the levy.
Like any tax the levy will act as a disincentive to production: that is the natural law of taxation.
Moreover the levy is not part of the revolving fund.

The revolving fund is the levy paid by growers which is returned in subsequent years, according to the Australian Wool Council's determination of the market and demands upon the fund for future financing plans.
For example, the year 1988/89 $166 million was returned to growers. This was an exceptional amount being two years worth of contributions 1981/82, 1982/3.
On any calculation the increased levy of 25% would not be revolved under ten years, nor with interest payments.
A guide on this would be that after the 1974/75 wool crisis funds were withheld until 1981/82, some eight years.

It is interesting to note in 1975 when the Whitlam Cabinet recommended a lowering of the floor price, the decision was overturned in Caucus on May 28th 1975. An article in the Australian at that time reads:
The Labor Party Caucus yesterday overturned the Cabinet decision on wool and restored the floor price to 250c a kg in a 52-29 vote.
The result was a decisive triumph for the party and the back bench over Cabinet.

An estimated crowd of more than 300 wool-growing and farming interests waited outside Parliament House during the Caucus meeting and were first told of the likely reversal by the Federal Country Party leader, Mr Anthony.

Mr Wran, anticipating the arguments of those ministers who would follow him, put up a powerful case to maintain the 250c floor price. His amendment was seconded by another NSW backbencher, Mr J. Kerin.
But this time he's in Cabinet himself, part of the club, and has treasury leaning on him, and he has wilted.
Returning to the question of the revolving fund: It is not, however, subject to interest accumulation for the growers and is eroded by inflation.
So even if a payment was to come about after 10 years, the money would be worthless.
It will be dead money spent on servicing the AWC's accumulated debt.
Surely this is the most powerful signal to growers regarding production.
ABARE has underestimated the strength the levy plays in affecting the supply side of the argument.
The growers have clearly indicated that they are willing to accept a 25 per cent levy for the next 5 years to maintain the 870 floor price over the next 5 years.
The floor price at 870 is subject to devaluation by way of the Australian dollar falling and high inflation rates.
So, in real terms, the price will decline, but in a far more managed and less sudden and damaging way than has been effected by the Government.
To that end, I support the amendment brought forward by Senator Boswell to amend the legislation.
In the final analysis, it should be the Australian Wool Growers and their representative determining their future on this issue.
In supporting the amendment I recognise that I am crossing the floor in disagreement with my coalition partners.
More particularly, I cannot support the Government on this issue.
My support is with the Wool Growers of Australia and their express desire to maintain the orderly marketing system for wool, and more particularly to maintain the existing floor price.
I quote from 2 parts of an article from the Australian Financial Review:

In another last-ditch bid to convince Mr Kerin that the corporation's position was soundly based, a number of its non-grower board members sent him a letter yesterday stressing their conviction that the floor price should be held.

The letter was signed by the four board members selected for the position on the basis of their financial, marketing or commercial expertise-the deputy chairman and managing director of the Fletcher Jones group, Mr David Jones, the chairman of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation and former chief executive of H.J. Heinz Australia, Mr Ernest Barr, Nestles chairman Mr Tony Whatmore, and the managing director of investment banker Axhurst International Pty Ltd, Mr Rob Douglass.
. . . the Wool Council of Australia president, Mr Chip Sawers, that Japanese buyers were ready to return to the market.
In a statement from Tokyo, Mr Sawers said Japan would need to buy wool within a week to avoid mill shutdowns.
Its raw wool stocks were down to 10,000 bales.
``The processing pipeline is empty and speculation over the floor price is causing a crisis for the wool industry,'' Mr Sawer said:
Finally I quote from a letter from a man with 14 years experience as an economist with the IAC, the latter part at a fairly senior level. Referring to Mr Kerin, this man wrote

Nowhere has he mentioned the nominal write-down of production assets and, thus, of funds employed, arising from a lower floor price (at 700c this would amount to at least $8.5 billion assuming average sheep area values fall from about $150 to $100). I wonder about the reaction from the banks.

Australian wool exports have rescued the Australian economy on many occasions. While the Opposition agrees with the Government that raising the levy to 25 per cent is a bit steep and, indeed, that 20 per cent is more applicable, the interference by the Government to lower the floor price to $7 per kilo clean at the same time as raising the levy will send many smaller growers to the wall. As a fine-wool grower, I realise only too well the problems of those in the industry growing stronger wool. But with likely changes in fashion, when next year or perhaps the year after the stronger wools could be in demand, with bulky knits, et cetera, the situation could reverse.

International buyers knew that they could place forward orders around the floor price and could be assured that the stability of that floor price would mean that the value of the wool bought would either be maintained or increased, but certainly not devalued. As Mr Hugh Beggs, the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, said:

I shall not endeavour to explain the Minister's rationale, that is his job, but I will say that the Board of the Corporation does take and always has taken very seriously its charter under the Wool Marketing Act.
The major parts of this are twofold:
(i) to increase the commercial returns to the Australian woolgrower; and
(ii) that the performance of its function and the exercise of its powers do not conflict with major Government policies.
He continued:
I refuse to accept that in the Corporation's submission either of these factors was neglected. The result is that of the Minister's judgment overriding that of the AWC . . .

On his own head be it. I am fully aware of the disappointment and concerns of the industries but, as Mr Beggs and many other officers of the industry have said, we do not have to like the Government's decision. We believe it is wrong; we believe the Government will be proved wrong. But we have to get behind the industry now, to set about pulling the industry together again, assuring our international markets that there will be no further reduction in the floor price. It is imperative that the debate stop now and Australians speak with one voice, both the industry and the Government. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills. I wish to make a few short comments as to what I believe the wool industry needs. What the wool industry needs, above all, is certainty as it seeks to plan its future. For this reason the Senate cannot responsibly take action that would result in this legislation failing or being delayed. The message that woolgrowers in Western Australia have given to coalition senators is that they do not want this to happen, with further uncertainty wreaking havoc with sales. They have had enough. The simple rules of the game are such that only the Government can amend a taxation Bill, and any effective blocking of these Bills by the Senate could mean that for the 1990-91 year the maximum rate of levy would be stuck at 10 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the 1987 wool industry legislation aimed to establish the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) on the level of a major private corporation, with determinations as to levy and floor price left to the AWC and the Wool Council of Australia as representatives of the growers, it is unfortunate that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has now acted to override the industry on both counts. I have never felt it right, as a senator for Western Australia, to state what the right floor price for wool should be. It should be a decision of the industry made in the fullest knowledge of market conditions in both the short and long terms. Whatever the merits of a floor price of 700c, we have a situation where the asset value of wool stocks is severely diminished, along with the credit rating of the AWC.

I can only state that in Western Australia, while many growers have strongly supported the argument that a lowering of the 870c floor price will not succeed in selling more wool, others-including many members of the Pastoralists and Graziers Association-consider that a lower floor price best reflects market realities. We must remember that we are dealing with an efficient industry which ultimately has to survive in the real world of international competitiveness and domestic input costs. It is an industry that has levied itself $190m annually for research and promotion. At the end of the day it is the growers who pay the bills. It is very sad that there has been so much publicity about problems in the industry and that any action has been delayed for so long in seeking to arrive at a possible solution.

Nor should we lose sight of the fact that the efficiency of the industry has meant a yield of 4.61 kilograms per sheep in 1988-89, from 166 million sheep, compared with a yield of 3.54 kilograms per head in 1945-46, when sheep numbers were 89 million. Production levels of 1,000 million kilograms are thus three times the level of the postwar period, when a stockpile of 3.8 million bales was the equivalent of 10 million bales today. While dispersal of that earlier stockpile took four years to clear, real prices were two to three times their current level. It is also a fact that the wool industry has shown itself capable of responding well to market signals. Thus, the 1970-72 slump in wool prices saw sheep numbers fall from 172 million in 1970-71 to 134 million two years later. We are not therefore dealing with an industry or with producers who are afraid of the ultimate dis- cipline of the market.

Now that a fresh scenario has, in effect, been forced upon the wool industry, it is to be hoped that the industry will be left to implement its own solutions without any further pressure from the Minister. The position of any major export industry depends far more upon the macro-economic climate that a government creates than upon individual decisions of Ministers in a regulatory capacity. The Minister who really deserves to be in the hot seat for this debate, therefore, is not the Minister for Primary Industries, but the Treasurer (Mr Keating). We are back to the inescapable truth that it has been the policy of the Hawke-Keating Labor Government to use high interest rates as a tool of economic management. This of course has added to the cost structure of Australian farms, along with other business enterprises.

One of the greatest concerns held by the industry, and by both sides of Parliament, is the size of the wool stockpile. I would emphasise, therefore, that the annual $220 storage costs per bale amount to a breakdown of $40 for actual storage, and $180 in interest costs-so great as to write off the value of the wool in a few years. I remind the Senate that these costs are courtesy of the Treasurer.

It is also an inevitable consequence of the Treasurer's policy that his high interest rates create a situation where the Australian dollar is over-valued to the detriment of the people who keep Australia going-the exporters. Let us not forget what a fine industry the wool industry has been in that area.

If the 870c floor price was considered a barrier to selling wool, then how much greater a barrier has been the over-valued dollar, courtesy of the Treasurer. Thanks to the economic management practised by this Hawke Labor Government, Australia in the 12 months to April had accumulated a current account deficit of $21.3 billion, 5.8 per cent of the national output. Our gross foreign debt stands at $148 billion. It is with this kind of background that the Treasurer is pressuring the Minister for Primary Industries to compel the wool industry to reach short term solutions that will sell more wool more quickly. While we would all agree that wool must find its markets overseas, for the health of the industry and Australian exports in the long term it is essential that solutions are geared to the viability of the wool industry rather than improved short term figures.

In supporting this legislation, the coalition does not endorse the economic management of this Labor Government that is a major cause of the difficulties of the wool industry. Long term, difficulties will be best tackled with a backdrop of responsible economic management and the maximum freedom for wool producers to decide their own destiny. Australia needs a viable, strong wool industry for our own national good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be speaking in support of the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1990, and I shall be supporting my colleagues on this side of the chamber in this package of Bills. I believe that these Bills are the best that can be done at present for the wool industry. I am not happy about the Bills; I have some reservations. That is the reason why I wish to speak for three or four minutes this afternoon. I do not want to go through the history of the wool industry or the state of the marketing arrangements at present. However, I refer anyone who is interested to Senator Panizza's excellent speech yesterday when he covered this topic in a most encyclopaedic manner. I felt it was the best speech that Senator Panizza has ever made in this chamber-which is what one would expect of someone whose lifetime had been involved professionally in growing wool.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to put on public record some matters that concern me. First, I believe that it is not the purpose of governments to set prices anywhere, least of all for commodities. Certainly it should not be for governments to support practices which distort the market signals. The principal reason that we are in the present mess with wool that we cannot sell is that the usual market signals have been blurred and suppressed by the marketing system that was in place. That has done the industry a very great disservice. At the end of the day a person is selling anything he has to meet the market. If people will not buy at one's price, one is left with the goods. It does not matter what one is selling, it is the market that dictates the price. There might be many complexities, but that basic fundamental cannot be evaded. One cannot embark on running cartels, which is what the Australian Wool Corporation has tried to do. It has tried to set up a cartel. There are two failings with that, quite apart from the fact that, historically, in the commercial world cartels do not survive. Firstly, one does not have a monopoly on the material, as other countries produce wool; and, secondly, there are alternative products, alternative man-made fibres, which can be used for the same or equivalent end results.

I am also disturbed by some of the misconceptions that have been promulgated in the public debate. One of those is that if there is any downward change to the price, the market for wool would collapse. That is a very dishonest argument. Anyone who buys commodities-it does not matter whether it is copper, cocoa or wool-knows that the price fluctuates. People who are buying the product are professionals. They are in there to make a profit. They make a bigger profit when the commodity is at a low price. Their professional skills and experience should guarantee them a profit when the price of the commodity goes up. Anyone buying commodities expects the market to go up and down. Obviously, it is desirable for those on both sides of the equation that those swings are not too wide, but sometimes they are uncontrollable.

The biggest concern I have about the public debate on the wool industry is the argument that is run, very dishonestly, that somehow or other that this is a private deal between woolgrowers, and that the Government has no part in the argument and should not be involved. That is the reason that I am on my feet this afternoon-because the Government is very much involved. The Australian Wool Corporation can only raise levies as a consequence of the legislation that this Parliament passes empowering it to do so. I have a marked aversion to passing legislation which raises taxation in any form. I can see the justification when the national interest is involved, and services to the nation are provided as a consequence of those taxation moneys raised. That is why we have personal income tax, sales tax and the other revenue gathering functions.

What the Parliament has done here, and what we are being asked to do today, is pass legislation which allows one private group legally to tax another private group. While that legislation exists-and that is why we are debating this matter this afternoon-the Government has a very real place in the debate. I reject entirely the argument that the Government should not be involved in this wool debate. I wish it was not. If I had my way it would be right out of it. If the woolgrowers wish to form a private cooperative and set up their own marketing agreement, that is fine, but only if that has been set up can they make the claim that it is their money.

The national interest is very much involved. We now have a great problem with our balance of payments. This Government has mishandled the economy to such an extent that we are spending roughly a billion dollars more per month than we earn. Wool is one of our great export earners. The organisation that has been handling wool sales internationally has not done so as effectively and as efficiently as it should. As a consequence, one of our great export income producing industries is not working as efficiently as it should. The national interest demands that the Government has a view in this circumstance to improve it for the benefit of all of us.

The other point regarding the national interest that is important is the fact that, as a consequence of this legislation and the levy raised-the 10 per cent which is now to be 20 per cent-there is a direct reduction in the taxation base from which the Treasury runs the country. It is not the growers' money exclusively that is being taken by the wool levy. It is a reduction of 20 per cent from every woolgrower's income which the Treasurer simply cannot tax, so taxation rates have to be raised to compensate for it across the rest of the community.

The national interest is also involved because the Commonwealth will be the guarantor of the loan moneys raised by the Wool Corporation, to the tune of about $2.5 billion. If for any reason those borrowings cannot be liquidated by the wool industry, the taxpayers of Australia will have to pay that debt. It is a very big debt. I hope it will not happen. If things are managed properly it will not happen. Nevertheless, legally that liability still exists. So on every count the Government does have a real interest in the wool industry at present. I reject utterly as being misleading and dishonest the argument that it is the private concern of the woolgrowers, and theirs alone. The nation is very much involved.

As I made clear earlier in my speech, I wish we were not involved. If I had my way I would not be involved at all in any price support or marketing schemes. Least of all would I have ever supported legislation such as we have before us or its predecessors. But the fact of life is that this system is in place, we have a crisis in the industry and we have to do the best we can for the wool industry. While I have reservations, as I have made clear during the last seven or eight minutes, about the direction we are taking here, I believe that in the circumstances at present it is in the best interests of the industry and the nation that this legislation be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1990. Some people have suggested that it is unusual for an urban resident to speak on legislation dealing with a major rural industry of Australia. But I think we all recognise that the wool industry is a major industry and, irrespective of where we live or what electorates we represent, we should all have an interest in the outcome of this matter. I also point out that as a teenager I lived on a farm and for three years I was press secretary to the agriculture Minister in a State government in South Australia, so I have had some interest in agricultural matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I will address my remarks to the central question about the conduct of a reserve price scheme for the wool industry. It ought to be remembered that it was the Whitlam Government that introduced the comprehensive reserve price scheme for wool that now operates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but Doug Anthony got it ready.

—Senator Panizza's party had 23 years to introduce it but it never did. It took a Labor government actually to introduce it. I remember the debates at the time that the floor price scheme was being established. The discussions were about putting a base in the market. In the early 1970s the average price for wool was about 27c a pound or 70c a kilo-an unbelievably low price. People at that stage were predicting the end of the Australian wool industry as we had known it over its previous 100 years. There was the biggest recession, the biggest downturn, in the history of the industry. Out of that grew the establishment of the floor price scheme, the reserve price scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The idea of the reserve scheme brought in by the Whitlam Government was to put a base so that one could not take prices into or below the basement. It was there to stop actions which occurred in the early 1970s. The accusations that were made that were reasonably valid were that there were cartel operations going on amongst overseas wool buyers that were unnecessarily depressing the price of wool, irrespective of the demand for apparel fibre in the world. So the floor price was established to put a base or a bottom in the market. We understood that because the world's wool industry was based in Australia-we dominated 80 per cent of the market-we would have an influence with that reserve price or floor price scheme. But none of us at the time that it was introduced by the Whitlam Government ever believed that the floor price would develop into a high ceiling price scheme for the wool industry. The reason the industry is in its present mess is that unfortunately the leadership of the industry tried to turn a floor price scheme into a high ceiling price; that is, instead of having a guaranteed price at the bottom through which prices could not fall, they put a high ceiling at the top through which prices could not fall. I think that the reason we have the problem is that the industry tried to affect a fundamental position of supply and demand and was caught out. It is a very painful price for it to pay to learn that lesson, but it is going to have to learn it. Unfortunately, many woolgrowers will suffer.

It has been estimated that the price of 870c was 30 per cent above the long term trend for wool prices in the world. Any attempt anywhere in the marketplace to establish a price 30 per cent above a longterm trend is obviously fraught with danger, no matter whether it is wool, wheat, oil, or any other raw material. When it is done, there ends up being a number of effects. First, the people who benefit from it are not necessarily the people we are trying to protect. This is what has happened particularly in the last 12 months in the wool industry in the world.
The first people who got the benefit from this excessively high reserve price were overseas wool producers. Why? Because they could sell their wool a few cents below 870c and sell their wool--

TALK.START.PARA: —But they would undercut the price of wool if we sold it at 600c.
—Yes, SenatorBoswell, they may be able--
—Order! Senator Schacht, you can address your remarks through the Chair.

—Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will respond to Senator Boswell's remarks that they could undercut it at any price. Overseas wool producers cannot undercut it at any price because their producers are less efficient than our producers and if we drop the price down to 600c they cannot produce the wool at a profit. We can, because we are more efficient at wool production than any other country in the world. If the price was dropped to 600c, we would remove from the marketplace internationally a number of producers who are our competitors. I would have thought that in the national self-interest and in the interests of the wool industry that would not have been a bad idea. SPEECH.PARA: It was pointed out to me a couple of days ago that in the mid-1980s the Americans, through their subsidised grain prices, established a subsidised price for their wheat that was far too high. What happened? The Australian Wheat Board moved in and undersold the Americans by a few dollars per bushel and got a lot of extra markets and an increased price because we were able to sell below the American price. That was in the mid-1980s. It benefited our producers because the Americans tried to rig the wheat price too high. Unfortunately our wool industry did not learn from the experience of the American wheat producers in the mid-1980s. So the first people who benefited from this were the overseas wool producers. By raising the price too high, normal supply and demand starts operating. Other producers of alternative apparel fibre can come into the market and undercut us.

Who else are we supporting? We are supporting cotton producers around the world by removing wool from that part of the market by making the price too high. Above all else, we are supporting the natural enemy of the wool industry over 30 or 40 years, the synthetic producers. They are able to move in, undercut our markets and start selling. First, the efficient woolgrowers of Australia, those who had made a number of decisions to produce the wool that could sell irrespective of the price of 870c-those who produced the superfine wool and carpet wool-suffered. They can apparently sell their wool, but they are now being asked to pay a 20 per cent levy to subsidise those who cannot sell their wool.
