SPEECH.PARA: The thing I want to conclude on is the question of the economic changes going on in Australia. The coalition has argued and put forward cases for the need for micro-economic reform in many areas. I do not disagree with a number of areas it has identified where there has to be substantial change to the way industries are run. But the Opposition cannot have it both ways. It cannot stand up and say: `Let's clean up the wharves. Let's clean up road transport, shipping, civil aviation and so on, and get rid of the inefficiencies, the hidden subsidies, tariffs and so on', and then expect when the wool industry gets in a bit of trouble, to come to the Australian taxpayers to bail it out through revenue forgone and so on.

In the economy we are going to have to have in this country in the future, people will have to be responsible and take it on the chin when they make a bad economic decision. The Australian Wool Corporation made a bad decision in setting the reserve price at 870c a kilogram and it is going to have to take it on the chin, unfortunately for its growers, but that is a fact. It cannot then ask us to have micro-economic reform and changes when other groups in the community take it on the chin and expect to escape its own responsibility, as unfortunate and as difficult as that is.

I hope that in the future the wool industry, through the Wool Corporation, will understand from this debate that the fundamental economic lesson is that it cannot jack up the price beyond a sustainable level on the basis that it can lead its own growers into some economic nirvana because it can control the price. This whole episode in the wool industry over the last 12 months proved that even if we have 80 per cent of the world's wool producers, we cannot jack up the price and get away with it. It is going to have an economic cost not only to the wool producers but also to the Australian economy. I believe Mr Kerin has been correct in his actions over the past few weeks. I believe the Government is correct in bringing forward this legislation and not accepting the recommendations of the Wool Corporation. I believe, above all else, that the Government's biting the bullet two days ago and telling the Wool Corporation that the price had to be reduced to 700c was the correct decision and is in the long term interests of all woolgrowers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to thank honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1990. We are facing the question of the very viability of one of Australia's major industries. Indeed, of course, the consequences throughout the economy, particularly through the loss of export income, are such that they merit the very full debate and very well considered interventions that have been made by honourable senators during the course of the second reading debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The 20 per cent maximum tax rate that has been recommended in this Bill is only part of a package which the Government sees as necessary to help ensure the long term viability of the industry and, as a consequence, the Australian economy. One is talking about a number of variables, obviously, including pricing policy, and borrowings, marketing and promotion strategies. All these matters come into the full package, though at this stage this chamber only has the question of the wool tax maximum rate before it.

It is quite proper that honourable senators have addressed other matters, particularly the question of the floor price scheme. I think that basically Senator MacGibbon said what in large measure I would like to say-that really the market has determined the situation that we have reached today. There is a big difference having a floor price scheme, which acts as an income support scheme, as opposed to providing, if it can be achieved, that minimum stability which is required in the industry. But it certainly cannot be achieved if there are inexorable movements of the market, which have occurred over the last several years.

I believe that the loss to growers that was mentioned, for example, by Senator Boswell in his very well considered interventions on their behalf, essentially must be sheeted home to the market, which has made its determination about the price it is prepared to pay in relation to this major export commodity. To continue to stand against that trend is to court disaster for the industry.

After the most exhaustive discussions between, in principle, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), the industry and other sources of advice, the Government certainly believes that the package which Mr Kerin favours, and which has been adopted by the Government, is the only sensible course which this Parliament could give its adherence to. I believe that to do anything less would be to abrogate the responsibilities of government and of parliament.

Once again Senator MacGibbon and I find ourselves in agreement-which is rare enough-in our belief that, the Parliament having decided on this structure, responsibilities have to be sheeted home to the Parliament and the executive Minister in terms of the Act which has governed this industry for many years. The Government believes that any abrogation of the course upon which we find ourselves embarking would lead to consequences which would be more difficult and cause greater pain and greater hardship out in the industry.

I thank those honourable senators who have indicated their support. The Government, of course, cannot accept the second reading amendment proposed by Senator Boswell. I commend the second reading of the Bill to the chamber.

That the amendment (Senator Boswell's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment to each Bill:
Page 1, clause 3, leave out `20', insert `25'.

This amendment amounts to removing the figure of 20 per cent and inserting the figure of 25 per cent in each of the Bills. I move this amendment on the basis I referred to in my speech during the second reading debate-that, had this been the form of legislation originally and had the Opposition as a whole, the coalition, publicly supported this legislation in this form originally, we might not see the disaster, that has been predicted by many Opposition speakers, which the whole process, including the lowering of the floor price, will bring to the Australian wool industry or the short term attitude towards the impact on the Australian economy that we are seeing by virtue of the passage of this legislation.

We understand that the pre-emptive moves of the Minister could be seen to make this appear unnecessary. However, it is only a ceiling. We believe that the Australian Wool Corporation should be given that ceiling within which to make its decisions and that it should be the decision-maker, not the Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst the National Party has sympathy with the amendment, we really cannot support it. The effect of the amendment would be to lift the levy from 20 per cent to 25 per cent to sustain a floor price of 700c. I have spoken with the industry and it does not see this as a viable proposition. If we could have amended the Bill from 20 per cent to 25 per cent and then amended the Bill further to include an 870c floor price we would have supported this amendment. We tried to do that. We spoke to the clerks and found that what we were trying to achieve was impossible under the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that we would be written off by the rural industry as not being realistic if we went out there and told the constituency that we were supporting a 25 per cent levy to sustain a 700c floor price. It is not required by the industry. It is not wanted by the industry. I do not think it is economically viable to go down this track.

I realise that the Australian Democrats are trying to support the wool industry but I would suggest that if they really want to support the industry they should change their policy on live sheep exports and a few things like that. If they were to change their policy on live sheep exports and a move a little way on those sorts of things they would really be helping the industry. We understand that they are trying to show solidarity with the industry but I do not believe that they are doing it in a practical way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept the amendment moved by Senator Powell largely for the reasons put so ably by Senator Boswell, whose real commitment to the wool industry no-one in this chamber doubts. But I feel that the Australian Democrats, with all due respect at this late hour of the session-and I do not want to prolong it-are posturing in this regard. The 25 per cent tax is a maximum. They cannot really believe that a tax rate would be imposed on woolgrowers by the industry up to that rate because, as Senator Boswell said, it is not required where one has a 700c per kilogram floor price. They just do not go together. The 20 per cent tax rate goes well as a maximum with the 700c per kilo floor price, but the up to 25 per cent certainly does not. It was always linked to the maintenance of the floor price at 870c per kilo.

SPEECH.PARA: So this is some posturing on behalf of the Democrats and cannot be accepted by the Government. They cannot believe that the industry and the woolgrowers on a 700c per kilo floor price could sustain a 25 per cent tax. That would be utterly disastrous for many hundreds or perhaps thousands more woolgrowers than would be the case if this Bill were passed in the form proposed by the Government-allowing the imposition of a 20 per cent wool tax. So the Government rejects the amendment moved by the Democrats and thanks the coalition for its support for this proposal.

Profile
Bert Cooper, AO

BERT (Officially Albert Thomas) COOPER is shortly to retire as Principal Parliamentary Attendant, a position he's held since April 1981. He's known to countless inhabitants of and visitors to both the Old and the New Parliament Houses because he joined the Parliament in November 1950. Bert Cooper has earned much praise and friendship from the seven Prime Ministers and seven Clerks of the Senate to whom he's been responsible over the past forty years. He's been invited to significant ceremonies such as the Party in the Senate Gardens which welcomed Prince Charles and Lady Diana, and the laying of the foundation stone for the New Parliament House. And now, on Australia Day 1990, he's been honoured with Membership of the Order of Australia for what his hometown paper, The Queanbeyan Age, called ``outstanding public service''. Nick Greiner sent a telegram. Bert Cooper was born on 26 March 1925 at Merricumbene on the Duaua River. When he was seven the family moved to Moruya, where he went to school until the age of 14. Then Bert moved around a bit. He earned one pound a week plus keep on a dairy farm called ``Mayfield'' in the Moruya area. Next, he was chosen to work in a Civic Construction Corps gang of eighteen, and used pick-and-shovel to build first the Nowra aerodrome; then the Currarong road to the bombing target on what is now called Point Perpendicular; and then an airstrip at Jervis Bay. At the end of the war Bert left the CCC and went beekeeping, an interesting but fruitful change of lifestyle as he met his future wife, in 1945, when transferring beehives to Dalgety on the Snowy River. But it was to be a five year courtship as June McPhie's father insisted that she could not marry until she was 21. So Bert continued to work on the farm and then, in 1949, moved to Queanbeyan. He worked first at the Government Sawmill at Kingston and later in the hardware section at J B Young's at Civic. Finally, on 14 October 1950, June and Bert wed at Queanbeyan.
They honeymooned in Melbourne (the furthest south Bert's ever been and he's only been north as far as Newcastle!). Then it was back to the house in Queanbeyan they've lived in ever since.

Bert and June have three children and eleven grandchildren, all currently living in Queanbeyan. June has worked in the Post Office at Queanbeyan for many years. Her helpfulness earned her the Rotary courtesy award in 1987. Prior to his retirement, Bert Cooper has been less visible than normal because he was assisting in a major furniture stocktake in the Hume, Queanbeyan and Kingston warehouses, and with the barcoding of all items of furniture in the New Parliament House.
Eventually there will be a full computer compendium of all furniture and its location. He is now back to reap the farewells from his many friends and acquaintances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 May 1990 (Hansard, pages 296 to 299), Senator Brownhill asked Senator McMullan, as Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. ``. . . I suggest that the Australian Taxation Office should give sympathetic hearing to those affected by the disaster who pay provisional tax . . . It would be much appreciated by small businesses and others in the community if they could be given a chance to adjust their provisional tax payments.''

2. ``. . . Another point with regard to the Tax Act . . . relates to new fencing and the fact that it is deductible only at a depreciable rate. If it is a flood damaged fence I believe there should be total deductibility in the year of expenditure because people have to rebuild their fences in order to ensure their stock remains in the right place.''
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Answer No. 1

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that the application for variation of provisional tax is normally required to be lodged before the due date for payment specified in the assessment or in the instalment notice. However, the Commissioner has power to extend the time for lodgment of the application and the Taxation Office will give sympathetic consideration to such requests by victims of the floods.

Where the taxpayer has paid the provisional tax, and the variation reduces the amount of provisional tax, the Commissioner can credit any overpaid amount in payment of income tax payable, or refund the provisional tax overpaid.
Answer No. 2

The nature of the taxation deductions available for new fencing depends on whether the damage caused by flood requires only the mending of sections of the fencing, or a replacement of the whole fencing.
Where a primary producer restores an existing fence to good condition by repairing, including replacing, a damaged section, the expenditure is fully deductible in the year the expenditure is made.

If the damage to the fencing is so extensive that it needs to be replaced in its entirety, the general rule is that expenditure incurred in erecting the new fence is subject to depreciation over its effective life, rather than to immediate deduction in full.

In addition, if the old fence had not been fully depreciated for tax purposes, the excess of the then depreciated (ie written down) value over the consideration received (which in this case would include any amount receivable under an insurance policy) is fully deductible.

The exception to the general rule preventing immediate deduction in full is when the fencing was erected to combat or prevent land degradation. Primary producers can claim an outright deduction for the cost of erecting fences which are primarily or principally used for the purpose of excluding livestock or vermin from areas affected by land degradation to prevent or limit the extent of land degradation in the areas.
